39230868.review:
게임 자체는 특이하고 재미 있다.
그런데 대충 눈치빨로 스토리 순서에 맞지 않게 명령어를 입력해버리거나 하는 경우 가차없이 버그가 걸린다.
오직 스토리만 따라가야 한다는 것이 감점요소
멀티 엔딩이라 2회차를 하거나 중간 세이브 지점에서 시작해야 하는데 똑같은걸 또 보는 느낌은 그냥 저냥 본 소설을 또 강제로 봐야되는 느낌이다.
물론 skip이 가능하지만 언제 어떤 명령어가 해금되는지 알수가 없어 그냥 의미 없이 혼자 피젯 스피너들 돌리듯 컨트롤을 꾹 누르고 있는 상황을 보자면 만원 가량의 금액은 조금 아깝다.
살려면 할인 때 사고 가볍게 즐기는 걸로 추천한다.

39212912.review:
잃어버린 역사를 남겨진 기록을 통해 재구성하는 게임.
무궁화호라는 세계를 조각조각 맞추다 보면 어느새 퍼즐을 완성시킨 자신의 모습을 발견할 수 있을 것.

39158863.review: I have to admit, reading logs to unfold the story in a VN was quite a refreshing experience for me. It was pleasantly surprising how at times, the game tries to involve the player muchh more than just 'click n read as fast as you can'. I especially enjoyed the [spoiler]reactor meltdown sequence[/spoiler]. Soundtrack feels well suited to the situation as well. The story is deep, capable of stirring up your emotions and the logs do a good job of tying you to the characters they mention. You may feel for them, sympathize wiht them, disagree with them, get mad at them as you read of their plight, ignorance & misdeeds. Definitely worth a go.

39155091.review: Amazing visual novel that actually shines with its interesting story instead of cute waifus. Definitely recommend this and its sequel Hate Plus.

39083556.review: There's nothing really groundbreaking in this story, but it's still interesting and fairly well implemented. I was able to get 96% of the files, but there were still some questions that the story didn't answer which was disappointing. In addition, the controls are sometimes incredibly frustrating, but other times they work well. The setup of how you interact with the computer is pretty nice, but there are some ease of use features that would be nice (that is, arrow keys scrolling, pressing up in the terminal to get your last line of code). The weirdest thing about the game is that I found myself in a love story type situation without realizing how I got there, but it's not necessarily a *bad* thing.

I didn't read any further but there is a pretty good chance they all killed each other...

38770505.review: Krásný smutný příběh o nepochopení a vzdoru zasazený do nijak zvlášť originálního, ale dobře prokresleného prostředí. 38745872.review:
On a line-by-line basis, this may be the best visual novel I've read.  The author can write... sentences.  The story that develops is tragic and touching in many ways.

If the author hadn't included the AIs, if we'd been left to discover what had happened and ponder it ourselves, it might have been a passable story.  But you must let both AIs comment on every letter, which slows the game down TREMENDOUSLY, and mostly they just make heavy-handed commentary and force us to answer inane questions (is slavery of women good?  It's totally messed up to teach women to read, amiright? ... and more in that vein).  One of the AIs is an interesting character, essential to the story, but her persistent hammering on me to make sure I got the message that slavery of women is bad, 'mkay? made her more annoying than endearing.

Throughout history, there have been two opposing views of stories and of art.  One view, the older one, says that the purpose of stories is to answer questions and shut people up.  Creation myths.  Stories about Jesus.  Soviet Realism.  Mein Kampf and the sculptures of Arno Breker.

The other tradition says the purpose of stories is to ask questions.  Is history made by great men, or small actions (Tolstoy)?  Is civilization built by rational choices, or by mercy and grace (Dostoyevsky)?

The question that Analogue ultimately asks is: Is it okay to destroy society if it's hopelessly patriarchal?

Is that a genuine question that's socially relevant for today?  Yes, it is, if you're a paranoid schizophrenic living in a fantasy world in which the Handmaid's Tale is relevant to the US in the 21st century.

In fact this is one of the few questions that contemporary "literature" Is allowed to ask, which is the reason I'm reading visual novels on Steam instead of the post-modernist crap found in literary fiction today.  The entire point of modernism, Marxist critical theory, post-modernism, post-colonialism, and everything else found in "respectable" critical theory today is to convince people to destroy Western civilization.  It's the same trick the Nazis pulled with "Kultur", just in the interests of different people.

Analogue's agenda isn't really to get you to ask that question; it's to surreptitiously get you to accept the answer "yes" to the question, "Is Western society today hopelessly patriarchal?"  That puts Analogue in the tradition of propaganda stories.

It isn't that hard to destroy civilization.  Western civilizations have fallen many times: demographic collapse across the entire region circa 1187 BC, the destruction of native North African cultures at the end of the Greek Dark Age; Rome destroyed by Christianity after 300 AD; the total destruction of Arianist (no, I don't mean Aryan) Christian Europe by the Franks and Byzantines; the destruction of the Sassanid and Byzantine Empires by the Muslims; the devastation of Eastern Europe and Asia Minor by the Mongols in the 13th century; etc., etc.

News flash:  Destroying civilization has never worked out well for women.

38671709.review: Very good game that has great character development and isnt just a some visual novel you sit around clicking and reading. It gets you more involved and lays out a great story that grabs your attention and emotion.

38644519.review: This game has an interesting premise, but it ruins it with flat gameplay and a somewhat heavy-handed storyline.  I would have liked more sections where you were navigating the Operating system independent of the different AI's, or just more chances to go back and forth between the AI's themselves.  There's no real events and just the barest amount of interaction you actually have with the different characters.  It's a very limited game, and while it kept my attention while playing, there wasn't much in the way of actual choice.

38594893.review: Analogue: A Hate Story is one of the most "literary" games of recent history, in a recent history which includes a great deal of games with significant literary merit, from Night in the Woods and Gone Home to Undertale. There's been, to understate the issue vastly, "controversy" around literary games, or as a certain toxic subset of the gaming community terms them, "SJW" games - usually called such because they have the audacity to include a queer character or characters of color or to critique some trend in dominant gaming culture. I am an unabashed "SJW" or "social justice warrior." I have a full page dedicated to doxing me on a prominent alt-right website. I also think that while it absolutely deserves its place in the "canon" of video game history as a game which managed an impressive amount of storytelling with an incredibly small amount of art assets, and indeed made a fairly impressive effort at social critique, Christine Love's Analogue: A Hate Story ultimately fails as a game and as a social critique. Before elaborating, I do want to warn people who don't know what they're getting into that Analogue is more or less a space opera retelling of Margaret Atwood's The Handmaid's Tale, a harrowing novel about rape and misogyny. Both of those things exist throughout Analogue's narrative and intentionally discomfort the player. The game also has an undercurrent of fetishistic sexuality which is not something I find objectionable in itself, but which is handled in ways that seem quite hypocritical given the narrative the story is telling. At one point, for instance, one of the artificial intelligences who delivers the majority of the narrative in Analogue becomes angry with the player's character if the player chooses to dress the character in a particular outfit - an outfit which the game provides and which the character invites the player, in character, to dress her in. Full disclosure: my distaste for this game is absolutely driven by a personal dislike of the out-of-game politics of its creator. Christine Love has been a vocal spokesperson for transgender people and is perhaps the most visible openly transgender woman in gaming. She has also shamed a young transgender woman for having the audacity to praise Love for being a trans woman in games, because she has had "the surgery" and considers that part of her life over with. The games she writes are filled with transgender themes, but as the author she is downright condescending and insulting to anyone who wants to examine how these themes are dealt with. Do I recommend the game? Yes. Am I a fan? No. Analogue: A Hate Story is one of those terrible literary books you have to read in high school, and you should totally read/play it, but it's still not very good.

37847700.review:
As one of the first Visual Novels I'd ever heard of, Analogue: A Hate Story did not dissapoint. Underneath the moe veneer lies a fairly well written neo-feudal story that was an utter pleasure to read. I went in expecting something completely different, and instead I got a novella! Hard to beat. 

If you're like me and tend to cringe away from the more oversaturated tones of the waifu world, I would still give this one a chance. There are actual narrative reasons and some fun concepts played with here, and while the main narrative may not be your cup of tea, the secret meaty story juices within should definitely satisfy your palete. 

Secret meaty story juices/10

37842600.review: I've come back to this story a few times since purchasing it because it's really that good. The story and characters are well written, and the entire game feels very polished. The way the game lets you interact is engaging and feels meaningful. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys visual novels, or wants to try one for the first time.

37558012.review: If you are wanting to take a chance on visual novels, or just looking for a unique story, you should pickup Analogue: A Hate Story. While a lot of VN's focus on love stories, Analogue: A Hate Story offers up a more mystery-like story, asking you to explore what happened to a long lost starship. Without giving away too much, it's a fascinating mashup of history and sci-fi, with a powerful story that will hook you to the end.

37393736.review:
This again is a visual novel that strongly sits on the "novel" side of things. The visuals in this visual novel are not all that fancy if compared to some other works and the story is mostly linear, with only a few shorter branches. You can apply a tiny bit of cleverness and skip over dialog branches, but your choices generally are very limited.

But it's still a genuinely good novel about a story and life aboard a lost space ship. I think you'll have a good ~4-9 hours if you like to read such stories.

37367634.review: This game was a major pleasent surprise! Came in expecting a cool little story, stayed for the humour of the AI's. In the end, I learnt so much about medievial Korea and was so inspired by the story told here I ran a Numenera P&P campain off of it.

37313075.review:
基本的にノベルゲーはそんなにやらない質だけれど、このゲームは初っ端の演出からプレイに引き込まれた数少ないゲームのうちの一つだ。正直あまり期待はしていなかったので、クリア前後で落差が大きい分快哉も十二分だった。

ゲーム進行はAIに手がかりを提示され、主にログの断片を読み解いて過去に起きた事件の真相に迫って行くという形で進んでいく。最終的に事実が判明した時、何が正しく何が間違っているかどちらともいえない状況下で選択を迫られ、プレイヤーは頭を悩ませられることになるだろう。それゆえに迷って決断した後のエンディングの感動はひとしおである。悲劇を喜劇へと変えるのはあなただ。

日本語訳も素晴らしい。
褒めたのでそろそろPLAYISMさんよ、続編のHatePlusのローカライズまだですか？4年くらい待ってる…

36882183.review: A surprising game that grabs you by the lapels and doesn't let go. To say more would be to ruin the rich and complex storyline

36671237.review:
남존여비를 화두로 놓고서
도대체 이 AI들은 무엇을 말하고자 하는걸까?
그리고 제작자는 뭘 말하고 싶은걸까?

심도있게 다루고자 했다면 기록을 읽을때마다 AI를 마주해야하는 메커니즘이나
어중간한 미연시같은 도전과제는 만들지 말았어야 했습니다.

특히 읽는 기록마다 AI한테 보여주는 방식은 마치 수학문제집 옆에 정답과 해설을 펴놓는 기분이었습니다.
그렇다고 이 작품이 뭘 말하고자 하는지 명확히 전달되지도 않았습니다.
더구나 AI와 기록을 작성한 여러인물들의 생각들을 채 곱씹어보기도 전에, '이래서 그랬다, 그래도 어쩔수없는거잖아? 당연했던거야, 역겨울거야'와 같은 평가를 먼저 내리게 되니깐, 플레이하는 입장에서는 점점 기록을 읽기 전에 먼저 AI한테 가져다 주기만 하게 되는 상황으로 바뀌어버렸습니다.

남존여비라고 전개하는 과정에서 등장하는 남성들의 묘사는 굉장히 구식이며, 그에 반대로 여성들의 행동과 사상에 대한 묘사는 마치 16세기 남성과 21세기 여성이 살아가는 과정을 그린것 같은 느낌이었습니다.
남존여비가 옳지 않다라는 말을 하고싶었다면 굳이 일일히 설명하지 않더라도 충분히 드러낼수 있는데 하나의 AI는 피해자이고,
또다른 AI는 부역자 같은 구도라서, 충분히 더 잘 그려낼수있는 그림을 귀찮아서 스케치만 하고 내버려둔 꼴입니다.

어째서 갑작스레 '유교탈레반'같은 사회분위기가 지배적으로 깔리게되었는지에 대한 묘사도 상당히 손쉽고 간편하게 넘어가려는 모습이었습니다. '그 전에는 무슨일이있었는지 몰라.'라는 말로요.

그리고, 잘 진행하던중에 명령어를 입력하는 과정때문에
엔딩을 보고나면 기억에남은건 주제가 아니라 명령어 밖에 남지 않았습니다.

수동적인 비주얼노벨 구조를 탈피해 능동적으로 AI와 직접 대화하는 느낌을 주기위해 시도한 모습은 정말 좋았지만,
단순히 서구 사회에서 보기에 특이한 요소들만을 잘 짜깁기해 만든 투박한 구성물이라는 생각입니다.

압도적으로 긍정적이라는 평가가 도대체 어떻게 달려있는지 이해가 안될정도로...
입소문난 맛집인데 어느누구도 어떤메뉴가 맛있는지 모르는 상황같네요.
남존여비가 메뉴인줄 알았는데 간판이었던거고요.

36581169.review: really good game. interesting story, makes you pretty damn emotional, good characters, and very, very bittersweet. my mistake was playing this to cheer up after a tiring day... it just made me feel even worse. but in a good way. play this game, it'll definitely make you feel things.

36314749.review: It is a game that shows about humanity and ethics of how humans treat each other if history is lost. The story has a few twists. If you like graphic novels and dont mind long reading, this is the game for you. Plus computer inputs.

36237434.review:
(warning, spoilers)

You walk into a room to discover that it's full of corpses, the owner is missing, and the one person standing there, alive among the bloodstains, is actually really nice, and would be very happy to talk about anything - other than the corpses.

Welcome to Analogue. It's horrifying, it's depressing, it's kind of inspiring. It's also the most accurately subtitled thing I've ever seen. A lot of games entertain me; Analogue also makes me think. Designers talk a lot about 'hard choices' and 'no easy solutions', but this is the first choice-including game I've played where there actually was a lack of an easy solution, instead of an easy solution walled off by the arbitrary will of the author.

Also, it actually justifies the limitations of the format in-story. Seriously, wow. How do people do that?

It's only five hours long, which is really short for the price, but they're a first-rate five hours. It is genuinely brilliant.

36075864.review:
많은 사람들이 본 게임에 나오는 유교적 요소를 높게 평가 하지만,
그것은 서양사람들에게 신선한 요소이며 배경셜명을 훌륭히 해낸정도이다. 
사실상 이게임을 제대로 평가하려면  유교적 요소 그 자체보다는 
어느 문명왕조에 있었을 법한 이야기라는 데에 초점을 두어야한다고 본다.

고작 그 몇천명밖에 되지 않는 사회에서 고작 권력하나 얻어볼려고
인간들이 어디까지 추악해지는지 
매우 선명하고 고려가요급으로 적나라하게 실감나게 드러내보인다.
이 적나라한 부분이 사실상 이 게임의 핵심이다.
스토리의 짜임세가 꽤나 높은편이라 나는 이 부분에 더 점수를 주고싶다.

사실 유교적요소를 더 높게 평가 하지 못하는 이유가
게임 자체가 왕가와 세도가들의 이야기를 탐구하기 때문인데,
이런 이야기는 굳이 유교가 아니여도 다른 소재로도 충분히 표현 가능하다고 보기 때문이다.
(다수의 한국 리뷰어들이 우리나라보정이 되어있는 경향을 보인다.)

처음 시작할때 나오는 플레이어의 목표 자체는 너무나도 단순해서 
겜진행도 20프로만 되어도 조건만 갖추면 금방 완수가 가능하다. 
이부분이 조금 아쉬운 부분이라고 본다.

초반에 나오는 후원자가 조금더 깊게 개입해서 
조금 더 다양한걸 요구하여 플레이어가 따르거나 말거나 하는 방식이 더 좋았을지도 모른다.
이렇게했다면 멀티엔딩의 장점을 조금 더 잘 살릴 수 있었을지도 모른다.

평점 8.5/10

34795245.review:
I must say, I'm overwhelmed by this visual novel.

It is surely not just "a game you play for fun" but something you just play to uncover a story, to immerse in that story, in the universe and all.

To cover up some basic points:
- Yes, it is a LOT of reading
- Besides some Clicking and Reading and some immersive light "console typing" - no Game Mechanics
- Yes, there are Anime Figures in it, no they don't show much skin and there are just two

If you are looking for one of those things - sorry, can't be found here.

But tell you what? It doesn't need more to make an incredibly intense story! To build up Emotions and Characters. Heck, even those I did not talk to felt some kind of "real". I hatet them, I loved them, I felt bad, angry, even nervous.

This game has one of the best Stories I "experienced" in ages. I say experienced because I kind of totally immersed while playing that game. I wanted to know EVERYTHING. I didn't just hunt down every achievement, I wanted to learn everything I could from the game, because it is so well made and because the Information in this game are based on a real period of thinking in Korea. 

I strongly reccomed this game to everyone who loves good stories, maybe who wants to learn something and to everyone who likes immersive games.

34048386.review:
Overall I am quite mixed about this game.

There's not much to talk about in terms of gameplay since it is mostly a lot of reading, so the comments will have to be a vague overview of the story.

If you are wanting to play a novel because you like solving mysteries or experiencing grand ideas, this game is not quite a good fit. There is no complex mystery, nor are the central ideas all that deep or difficult to grasp. This is because the plot pushes a one-sided argument about society, and really, two balanced sides are needed in order to be really explore an idea in an interesting way. On the other hand, the setting and atmosphere is done rather well. There are one or two numbering/math errors if you pay too much attention to details (as if you were a detective or something) but overall I would have to say that this is a well-assembled game that, unfortunately, just happen to miss the vital points which I find enjoyable in novels.

As a side note. It is very short. That's expected, of course.

33617102.review:
Сначала я хотел начать свою рецензию так: "канадцы покурили травы и решили создать игру про корейцев..." Но теперь, зная, чем всё кончается, я должен взять более серьёзный тон.
Эта игра замышлялась как критика патриархальных устоев, а вышло - обличение звериного оскала феминизма. Такой сценарий мог написать только абсолютно бесчеловечный автор. Я не обвиняю Кристину Лав - это не она такая, таков современный Запад. И конечно же, мне жаль преступника - он страдал, очень страдал. Но блин, страдал он один, а из-за этого были загублены тысячи, возможно, десятки тысяч человеческих жизней - стариков, детей, УГНЕТАЕМЫХ ЖЕНЩИН, которые ни в чём не были виноваты. Это гипертрофированный индивидуализм Запада, где каждый готов ради собственных интересов убивать направо и налево. Этот чудовищный эгоизм однажды породил такого монстра, как фашизм и даже сейчас под лозунгами демократии и освобождения меньшинств убивают миллионы людей, втаптывают целые страны в прах, в каменный век. Кто знает, каких ещё чудовищ исторгнет из своих зловонных недр Западная цивилизация. Я уверен, что рано или поздно она сама захебнётся в собственной желчи и погибнет. Она уже гибнет, она уже не может воспроизводить себя и белые европейцы вытесняются мигрантами...
И я больше чем уверен, что настоящие корейцы, особенно северные, никогда не поступили бы так, как преступник. Потому что в корейцах очень развито чувство локтя, долга, коллективной ответственности. Я общался с ними, я смотрел корейские фильмы, я знаю это.
И та культурная парадигма, которая так громится в этой игре - ни что иное, как конфуцианство, на котором построена вся Дальневосточная цивилизация. Даже сейчас, когда нравы стали намного свободнее, конфуцианская мораль глубоко сидит в дальневосточных людях. И так ли это плохо? В наше время дальневосточные государства являются одними из наиболее успешных и динамичных стран мира. А всё благодаря потрясающей трудовой дисциплине, которая коренится в том же конфуцианстве.
Игра критикует конфуцианство как бы с гуманистических позиций, но она забывает, что главный принцип Конфуция - это жэнь, человеколюбие. Просто это человеколюбие через порядок и соблюдение норм. Младшие почитают старших, старшие заботятся о младших и все знают своё место. Разве в этом нет глубокого смысла?
Мы, русские, никогда не станем конфуцианцами, нам это чуждо. Но у нас есть собственные, евразийско-византийские корни и неплохо бы вспоминать о них хоть иногда.
Вот на такие серьёзные мысли навела меня История Ненависти. И надо сказать, это можно поставить ей в плюс, потому что редко когда игры наводят на серьёзные мысли. Я даже могу эту игру порекомендовать, при всей тлетворности её идеологии. Ибо сделана она хорошо, нетривиально, сюжет неплохо закручен, проходить интересно, присутствует реиграбильность. Но лично у меня она вызвала чувство глубокой фрустрации. Ну не мог я наслаждаться романтическим концом после того, что прочитал. Возможно, вам в этом отношении повезёт больше.

А теперь вкратце обрисую сюжет, чтобы написанное выше было понятнее.

Значит так, было у старого Смита три сына - бабник, дурак и пьяница. Это только присказка, сказка будет впереди. В любом случае, имена всех этих корейцев невозможно запомнить. Я и не запомнил. Хорошо, что в игре есть генеалогические схемы, по которым можно посмотреть, кто кому сват, а кто брат.

Канва такая: главный герой - детектив из далёкого будущего, которому историческое общество поручило расследовать причины гибели экипажа древнего звездолёта. Он был запущен с Земли с целью колонизации соседней звёздной системы. По моим подсчётам, со времени старта звездолёта прошло не меньше 1000 лет, из них 600 лет он болтается в космосе в безжизненном состоянии. собственно игровой интерфейс представляет собой бортовой компьютер этого звездолёта, в котором копается главный герой.
Первое, что мы видим - это консоль с командной строкой. Через неё придётся вводить различные команды. Потом она нам ещё понадобится, ох как понадобится, но первым делом с неё нужно активировать искусственный интеллект, с которым мы будем работать. Искусственных интеллектов на корабле два, каждый имеет графический интерфейс в виде девушки, причём эта девушка наделена чертами личности.

Хён Э - ИИ архивной системы. Она доступна сразу. Хён Э придерживается достаточно эмансипированных взглядов, но при этом романтична и любит поболтать. Что не удивительно, учитывая, что она провела на корабле 600 лет в полном одиночестве (второй ИИ был отключен).

Мюьт - ИИ системы безопасности корабля. Изначально отключена. Для её активации придётся узнать пароль администратора. Мьют - девушка традиционных взглядов, должна понравиться сексистам. Однако при этом она несколько грубовата и любит посплетничать. Мьют и Хён Э сильно не любят друг друга, и у каждой есть свои секреты.

По ходу игры нам придётся читать архивные документы и логи, глушить перегретый реактор и даже переодевать Хён Э в разные нарядные платьица. Но последнее - уже баловство, я считаю. Мы же сюда пришли серьёзным делом заниматься, не так ли?

Суть произошедшего на корабле. Примерно 900 лет назад там произошла какая-то социальная катастрофа, в результате чего население звездолёта скатилось в средневековье. Что именно случилось тогда, мы так и не узнаем, об этом рассказывается в игре-продолжении Hate+. Установившееся в результате катастрофы общественное устройство является копией традиционной Кореи эпохи Чосон. Оно жутко традиционное, регламентированное и патриархальное. О нелёгкой женской доле в этом обществе и будет вестись повествование.
А 600 лет назад все они внезапно умерли.

В новелле присутствует юрийный эпизод в качестве ответвления сюжета, также можно клеить ИИ-девушек как от лица женщины, так и от лица мужчины.

Что ещё интересно в этой игре - что от того, какую концовку вы получите, зависит то, как вы будете проходить роман-продолжение Hate Plus. Таким, образом, его можно пройти с Хён Э, Мьют или с обеими сразу, если вы умудрились получить гаремную концовку. Это делает обе новеллы чертовски реиграбильными. Лично я закончил Хейт Стори с Хён Э и с ней сыграю в Хейт плюс, но потом пройду обе игры ещё по два раза - с Мьют и с гаремом. Осталось только дождаться, когда доделают русификатор к Хейт Плюс. Он уже готов на 90 %.

33580203.review:
プレイ前「ちょっとクセのあるキャラデザインだなあ。かわいくないわけではないけど、ほかの人が熱狂するほどのものじゃ」
プレイ後「*Hyun-aeちゃんかわいいよ*Hyun-aeちゃん」
ってなるゲーム。

一瞬ぽろっとテキスト表示しておいて、それを読み切る前に別のテキストに書き換えてしまう演出ずるい。あれで心撃ち抜かれちゃいましたよ。
[spoiler]ただ数回しか二択選択してない段階で、プレイヤーに好意を見せたというのは唐突だったような気がする。一体どこを好きに……。[/spoiler]


読書はたいていの場合一人でするもの。
これをAIキャラと一緒に読んで、感想や意見を言い合いながら（一部誇張……プレイヤーは二択でしか意思表示できないし）読んでいくというのは、なかなかに面白い体験でした。

ただし、序盤はすこし苦痛。
一見関係なさげなテキストを読まされ、登場人物はなじみが薄くて似たり寄ったりに感じてしまう人名。
正直頭が混乱してる中、わけもわからずマウスをポチポチしていく状態でして。
でも中盤の山場を越えたころには大分人間関係や背景などもわかってきて、ストーリーにのめりこんでいきました。

中盤の山場は、人によってはつまづく人がいるかもしれない。けど、そんなに難しくないはず。
自分は*Muteの指示に [spoiler]最初バカ正直にその通りに実行してしまって[/spoiler] 一瞬はまってしまったものの、落ち着いて考え直し、なんとか自力でクリアしました。


結論。
18歳以上の方にお勧めではないでしょうか。
アダルト要素がある（パンツ脱ぐほどのものじゃない）というのもありますが、エグい描写もあるし、いろいろ読解が難しいということもあるので。
（クリア自体は簡単です。ストーリーや人間関係を把握するのが少々ムズイ）


あと続編の日本語翻訳お願いします！！

33312669.review:
Analogue: A Hate Story (PC - Steam) - 5/10

Итак, по сюжету нас отправляют на древний космический корабль, утерянный n-ое чисто лет (веков) назад, чтобы восстановить и скопировать данные, попутно разузнав о причинах гибели экипажа и, соответственно, провала миссии. А помогать нам в этом будут две девушки ИИ с того самого корабля. Звучит оно может и заманчиво, но по факту все несколько иначе.

- По началу в происходящем вообще ни черта не понятно и просто скучно. Множество корейских имен лишь добавляет путаницы.
+ Постепенно сюжет начинает набирать обороты, многое проясняется, появляется какая-никакая интрига, к именам отчасти привыкаешь.
+- Герои в меру харизматичны и интересны, но прописаны не до конца. Их слова и действия зачастую противоречат самим себе, отчего страдает логика повествования.
-+ Текста в логах очень много и большая часть откровенно скучна. Интересны только комментарии ИИ - из-за них и читаешь.
- В игре есть интересная, но криво реализованная часть с плавящимся реактором. Да, почувствовать себя крутым хакером и вбивать команды забавно, но порой непонятно что надо делать, а время тикает. Начинается все неожиданно и если ты ни разу с начала игры не сохранялся (сохраниться в процессе спасения корабля нельзя) и играешь не по гайдам - пригореть может знатно.
- К тому же разработчики заставляют тебя сделать выбор, кого из ИИ спасать (основываясь на неполных знаниях), что просто глупо. По идее, есть тайная концовка со спасением обеих героинь (до которой можно додуматься на втором/третьем/четвертом прохождении или вычитав код в гайде), но опять же - выглядит это как читерство, а более логичный вариант с простым копированием файлов обеих ИИ почему-то не предусмотрен. Да и само поведение героинь в этом случае противоречит их же характерам. Т.е. концовку можно считать провальной.
- Многие вопросы так и остаются без ответа.
- Рисовка простенькая, задников нет.
+- Музыка нормальная - ни восторгов, ни отрицательных эмоций.

+ Есть очень годный фанатский перевод на русский язык. Странно, почему разработчики не связались с его создателями, чтобы официально добавить его в игру.
+ Есть достаточно подробный гайд на английском языке.

33258654.review:
I'm pleasantly surprised by this game.

I have some tendencies towards longer, lower-interaction and less-branching VNs, and this is none of those.

But I'm impressed with the way the gamplay has been implemented, and the way it naturally results in the choosing of routes. The soundtrack is properly atmospheric, and I was genuinely surprised by how pleased I was with the first ending I got for how... anticlimactic it ended up being.

Overall, this game has a few quirks that set it apart from the majority of VNs, and I think all of them have worked in its favor.

33085187.review:
Analogue: A Hate Story is a cross between a futuristic, dystopian sci fi novel and a dating sim. The writing is definitely one of its strong points. Each of the characters have a very clear voice and personality. The basic premise, as others I am sure have explained, is that it's your job to comb through the ship's records in order to find out what happened to the Mugunhwa, a ship that crashed.  But what it turns into is that you must convince the AI on the ship to actually release the records for you... and, for a variety of reasons, neither Mute nor Hyun-ae are in a hurry to do so. A fortunate side-effect, though, is that it gives you time to really delve into the story. I for one found myself not really caring for my original mission and instead just wanted to hear more stories. 

Anyway, I would recommend this game to anyone who has the patience to read long chunks of text. It's worth your while, even though it may not be for everyone. Likewise, I recommend this to anyone who wants an immersive story-driven game. The world building is very interesting, all the while keeping the actual graphics to a minimum.  Well done, indeed.

32961858.review:
Analogue is one of the better visual novels out there. Check it out.

Alright, to get a little more in-depth and probably spoilery: Analogue (and its sequel, Hate Plus), together form a character study of *Mute, one of the two A.I. ladies in all the screenshots. Analogue, by itself, is mostly a collection of fragmented journal entries written by people living on an isolated spaceship where society regressed to something like the intensely misogynistic Joseon Dynasty of historical Korea. The character of *Hyun-ae is also around, mostly as a satire of more typical visual novel heroines. There's an inconsequential framing device (the player character is a spaceperson on a mission to recover the data logs of the spaceship where everything went down) but that doesn't matter too much.

*Mute is the most complex character in the story, and she touches on a lot of themes. As an artificial intelligence, she's a transhuman person and her story raises a lot of thought-provoking transhumanist issues: what would immortality mean for a human (or human-like) consciousness? is it moral to program a consciousness that lacks free will? how might a transhuman consciousness process love, hate, and other emotions? As the most powerful person in a fiercely patriarchal society who also happens to be a woman, she demonstrates internalized misogyny and homophobia and invites the player to explore those issues as well. As the last survivor (almost) of a spaceship she was built to protect and a society that's now extinct, she has to struggle to find a new purpose in life. The character of *Mute manages to do all this heavy lifting while still being a fun, snarky, nosy, judgmental gossip who, like, talks vaguely like a valley girl.

Of course, *Hyun-ae is the one who shows up on all the screenshots and stuff. She's a relatively simple character, compared to *Mute anyway. *Hyun-ae's job, sometimes to the point of breaking the fourth wall, is to satirize visual novel heroines. She instantly (though not unconditionally) loves the player character, dresses up in cute outfits for them, craves their attention, etc., but the game goes and critically examines what might lead a person to behave this way. The element of satire goes way further in Hate Plus.

The bulk of Analogue is a collection of text logs written by the doomed crew of a huge spaceship sent from Earth at slower than light speed to colonize some distant planet but which ended up adrift in space. These provide the player with an autopsy of the regressive, misogynistic society in power at the time that an unknown tragedy killed everyone except *Mute and *Hyun-ae. Some are written by lowly peasants, some by rich nobles, some by men, and some by women. They sketch out an interesting and compelling cast of characters as well as the ugly culture in which they lived, and form rich ground for a lot of thinking on sociological and social justice issues. One of the most powerful themes that comes across in these writings is the fact that even though individuals are rarely malicious, the institutions they live in can be incredibly harmful. I would think most players would end up empathizing with the denizens of the Mugunghwa while simultaneously condoning their destruction (or at least sympathizing with their murderer), which is a great showcase of the writer's skill.

Unlike its sequel, Analogue can stand on its own. The ending doesn't resolve much, but the story doesn't present many dangling plot threads anyway. Anyway, now that I've made a short story long, go play it for yourself.

32834483.review:
As a few other review have said it can get quite dry at times, however I feel that this works well for the story as if there was a dramatic shift in every log then it would feel less genuine. You have to hunt for the story it's not just given to you. For once this is a visual novel that embraces the genera, and is not just a story with some button prompts and a nice background.

There are a few changes I would make to the game such as allowing you to see who you have shown what files to and swapping the back and forward buttons for the 3 menus (I mean come on it's only one more button and it would save a lot of time), but other than that I really enjoyed it. The story could be very confusing at times with all the Korean names with no visual reference but by the time I beat it I was fairly confident I know what all had happened.

This is a story that can get quite mature, less so with the character actions and more so with the reactions to events. I mean seeing a kid hit by a car is one thing, but seeing someone laugh about it is another (neither happens in this story). I quite liked how it all played out and appreciated how the story stayed feminist without being preachy or condescending.

Overall well done. And I congratulate the author!

32353667.review:
Analogue: A Hate Story is a Visual Novel, emphasizing the "novel" part. Meet the two A.I.s of a big, long lost and dead multi generation colony ship and read through the ship's log entries that unravel the story of the ships downfall and the personal tragedy of the "pale bride". This game has multiple endings, non linear storytelling (but a linear story) and the power to make you hate. The title is very honest. Reading through the log files, the creepy atmosphere and the unbelievable twist can actually make you feel pity for a person comitting genocide, and hate the persons family. Powerful and emotional writing. Top notch.

32171925.review:
There's no doubt that Steam has been flooded, for better or worse, by visual novels as of late.

Now, don't get me wrong, Indie titles are great, but amidst the endless stream of "waifu"-bait visual novels (VNs) you'll see here on Steam, I think you'll be hard-pressed to find many decent stories with an intriguing plot that aren't about getting in a girl's pants for an affordable price. That's par for the course when discussing visual novels, but that's also why I tend to trust VNs from well-known studios/devs, because at least you know you'll get plot while playing VNs of acclaim like [i]Clannad[/i], the [i]Grisaia[/i] Trilogy, or [i]The Devil on G-String[/i] in exchange for their premium price.

But, let's rewind time back to 2012, when Gangnam Style was top of the charts around the world and every tween and their literature teacher was dying to see [strike]Shaky Camera: The Movie[/strike] The Hunger Games. In this archaic age of yore, there were, quite frankly, no good visual novels on Steam, save for one: Christine Love's [i]Analogue: A Hate Story[/i]. Back then, I wasn't sure how much story ten bucks could really buy, but boy I was surprised.

Analogue eschews all the teenage high-school setting jazz you'll see in 99.9% of visual novels out there. Instead, it opts to tell the fate of a ruined colony ship, the Mugunghwa, in a decidedly sci-fi setting. It does this with considerable polish.
Analogue's presentation is simple, nothing more and nothing less required to tell its story, letting you explore the lore of the ship's mysterious downfall at your own pace as you literally read through logs like the investigator you are supposed to be. At the very least its more interactive than half the VNs on the market, with a very entertaining minigame thrown in halfway through the story. 

Now then, you can hold off on impulsively buying those tempting 11 Anniversary Lootboxes in Overwatch since for those same ten bucks, you get a substantial story and can brag to your friends all about the "Joseon" Era of Korean history.

And at the end of the day, what's more important? Getting yet ANOTHER Tracer legendary skin or knowing what "Joseon" means? You be the judge of that question.

Just uh...don't blame me [spoiler]if your 10 bucks gets you neither of those, in the end[/spoiler].

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
 [*]Absolutely riveting plot
 [*]Cute AI girl[spoiler]s[/spoiler]
 [*]Different outfits on a whim for Cute AI girl[spoiler]s[/spoiler]
 [*]More game interaction then smashing "ENTER" every 10 seconds
 [*][spoiler]Stop a nuclear explosion with your hacking skills[/spoiler]
 [*]A feminist game that makes sense
 [*][spoiler]You can achieve the impossible dream every indecisive teenage Light Novel main character wishes they could make by quite literally cheating the system[/spoiler]
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
 [*]No voice acting, but that's completely fine
 [*]Relatively short, but there actually is a sequel so more playtime there too I guess
 [*][spoiler]Learning about how unpleasant people from the Joseon Dynasty could be is disgusting[/spoiler], but that's the point
 [*]Not that I care but its based off of Korea and not Japan so you "purists" may have some beef with that.
[/list]

No but seriously. Play Analogue.

32093056.review:
You should really play this game.

It was one of those things that just stays with you, and you keep thinking about it the rest of the day after you’ve played it. It’s also not that long– I got 98% completion in, according to Steam, 2.8 hours. So it’s more than worth the investment.

There are two stories here. The frame story is that you are sent as part of your job to go through the records of a recently rediscovered lost ship/space colony that has been gone for hundreds of years. You head over and start sifting through the log files with the help of the ship’s AI. The second story is what actually happened on the ship. The setting is simultaneously a future dystopia and a past dystopia– the frame story takes place more than a thousand years in the future, while the secondary plot takes place six hundred years before that.

It’s hard to describe the game without getting into spoiler territory, but I’ll do my best: the gist of the secondary plot is that on this space colony, some unspecified disaster caused major social and educational regression and an extreme population reduction that ultimately resulted in the establishment of an extremely oppressive patriarchal society in which women rarely are allowed to leave the home and are often married off as young as 12 or 13. A young girl put in stasis before the disaster due to an illness wakes up hoping that a cure has been developed, only to find the world has gone to hell.

The game is simultaneously a reflection on the horrors of the past– a particularly disturbing post-game author’s note lets you know the circumstances are based very heavily on actual customs of Feudal Korea– as well as a warning about where we could head in the future. The girl wakes up and tries to tell her new “family” about her illness by emphasizing how thin and pale she is, but all the men hear is a woman’s whine and all the women hear is bragging about good looks, which would sound extreme if the exact same thing hadn’t happened to me in the past. It’s an examination of the ways women survive in such an oppressive society, and what happens to those who don’t fit the mold.

The final reveal of the girl’s storyline was something I saw coming by the time I got there but was hoping wouldn’t happen all the same.

The gameplay itself was clever, if simple. The navigation was freer than you usually get in a VN, as the interface is of a computer system you can explore more or less however you see fit– as the AI offers commentary– though the AI will dole out information based on how you interact with them so the story itself it ultimately nonlinear. In addition to reading snippets of the ship’s logs and chatting with the AI, there’s also a command input console where you can type in whatever you please to the ship’s computer. I thought the puzzles involving the commands were interesting enough to require some good thought while also logical enough to be solvable on your own.

The weakest part of the game to me was the ending of the frame story. The story itself is somber, serious, and tragic, but the AIs end up flighty, silly, and almost like caricatures. Like, after everything that’s gone on, Hyun-ae suddenly turns into terrible tsundere and decides she’s in love with you and wants to get married? What? The LAST thing she should be interested in after what she’s seen is some kind of weird relationship with a stranger. The tone shifts from torture and oppression to some kind of parody with no warning whatsoever, and it’s like she just forgets what you were looking at. It’s jarring, but also comes off as though the game doesn’t take its very, very serious subject matter seriously at all. “Oprression and mutilation destroy lives. CAN I BE UR WAIFU????” Just wat.

In the same vein, I thought calling the “best” ending a “harem” ending was ridiculously tacky. In a story where women are literally being forced into harems, just what the hell. Is it supposed to be a joke? Why is that something to joke about? Is it some weird attempt at meta-commentary on VNs? Wrong place, wrong time.

So yeah, the last five minutes or so of the game are… bad. They’re just bad, there’s no way around it. But overall? This is an engaging, emotional, tragic story with a message that hits close to home, and I really recommend it.

31799442.review:
Analogue: A Hate Story is probably the most hard-hitting visual novel I've ever played, which is saying a lot; I've been a VN fan for almost ten years now. It's short - I completed it 100% in less than 4 hours - but I made a couple save-related errors so I can't claim the game to be even 3 hours of content. But it really doesn't matter, because what the game does with its short story is so impactful that I can't see it being pulled off in any other way.

The soundtrack is good but, as with all visual novels, it can get a little repetitive after a while. There are 5 endings to reach, and while I have my preferences, they're all very serviceable and satisfying conclusions. But the meat of Analogue: A Hate Story is slowly cooperating with an unreliable narrator to unravel what happened on a spaceship that's been abandoned for over 600 years.

Analogue: A Hate Story will have you learning everything about people you will never meet, reading about relationships and conflicts that you can never personally witness, and slowly experience your heart being crushed by one of the most sympathetic AI characters ever written. You will find yourself questioning your own morals, and who knows? You may even end up embracing hate with open arms.

31345462.review:
As VNs go I feel really conflicted about Analogue. There were a handful of elements I was really impressed by, but ultimately I don't recommend it. It's frustration incarnate; more time invested in it brings the opposite of a sense of reward.

Analogue is a VN showcase of interesting ideas that are never seen through to their full potential. The setting is barebones, any mystery of the events on the lost colony ship doesn't have any real contrast with the experience of the player's blank slate agent; indeed throughout the game I felt the real mystery was finding out what was normality outside of the ship.

Evidently centuries ago there was development of human level AI and the resources to build giant colony ships to a destination so far away it'd be travelling for generations. But the player's character just accepts this as an inconsequential triviality, as though they're walking out to the wilderness to pick up a memory card from a crashed weather balloon a few miles out of town; where the world hasn't changed since the balloon's launch.

VNs without a strong plot or compelling characters reallly don't have much going for them. Analogue doesn't really possess either. Indeed, the bulk of the writing is incomplete logs about a crypt ship. Instead of this being a compelling slowburn of intrigue, many of these logs and letters read like they're all written in one voice, giving little individuality to what's meant to be wildly divergent experiences on the ship.

To make this worse, there's additional UI frustration as actually trying to progress through the VN has no obvious path; it's continually go to a log, then attempt to point it at 1 of the 2 main characters. Here at least there's a sense of individuality and characterisation, but that quickly wilts as there's instead an impression of neither being more than a heavy handed framing device - one is basically parroting a dogma of "Isn't a functional society the most important thing WITHOUT ANY EXCEPTION WHATSOEVER?" and the other displaying both staggeringly unsubtle withholding of information, and a need for continual validation. Both treat any response to any disagreement shockingly poorly, as though that verbal disagreement was the worst thing to ever happen to them.

The bulk of Analogue consists of the following: Trying to find to right log to read, then push at the right character to see if they will either release the next set needed completion or discuss their take on the other character aboard the colony ship, in the correct order. Advancing the storyline in this VN felt like a chore. Instead of a replay bringing revelations and discovering mistakes I'd made in hindsight - different perspectives on the same events for example - it felt I'd covered the meat of the content on the first pass, and later variations were last minute indulgences that never met much scrutiny as to whether they deserved inclusion.

Analogue greatly benefits from Isaac Schankler's music, ranging from mellow slice of life to urgency and impending catastrophy, and I'd say it's the strongest and most memorable part of Analogue. Additionally there was one segment with an element of a looming success / fail state that brought some badly needed focus with clear objectives and a sense of urgency to achievement them to the proceedings.

30217414.review:
Honestly, Analogue: A Hate Story is great. It's a wonderful analysis of gender roles and society, all packaged in this visual novel that uncovers the story piece by piece, nonlinearly. Sure, it's kind of on the nose at points, but it's well worth it. It's pretty short, so if that bothers you, maybe get the game on sale? I think it's worth the $10 because of the emotional impact, though.

Fair warnings to new players: be prepared to do a lot of reading (although that should be obvious) and keep separate logs from key turning points, because replaying is kind of tedious otherwise.

29943860.review:
Je n'ai parcouru que très peu de visual novels, et vu les critiques - bonnes ou mauvaises - que je parcourais sur quelques titres typiques du genre sur Steam, j'avoue que je partais avec un gros préjugé. Je craignais énormément de tomber sur des fan-fictions boursouflées, des histoires de Mary-Sue où les auteurs se projettent à mort... bref, on va dire que de base je n'étais pas le client idéal.

J'avais un peu entendu parler de Analogue en bien, et je me disais que s'il fallait vraiment toucher au genre histoire de ne pas mourir idiot, je ferais probablement celui-là... pas un grand choix hypé/passionnel, mais bon la curiosité était là.
Et quand le hasard d'un cadeau a fait que je me suis retrouvé avec ce titre en main, je me suis dit que c'était le bon signe pour s'y mettre, c'était la bonne conjonction... et bien m'en a pris.

Analogue n'est pas un simulateur de drague.
Au départ il s'agit d'une simili-enquête. Oui il y aura - un peu - de drague (quoiqu'on pourrait plus parler de l'évaluation de sa compatibilité et de choix de confiance) mais l'essentiel de la lecture du jeu consiste à essayer de comprendre ce qui a pu se passer dans un vaisseau spatial immense retrouvé à la dérive dans l'espace et dont toute la population est morte. On ne parle pas d'un équipage massacré par un alien. On perle de la population d'un vaisseau destiné à coloniser des planètes, le genre de bouzin abritant des millier d'âmes.

Le jeu ne baigne pas pour autant dans une atmosphère horrifique. Il n'y a pas de danger à affronter. Tout le drame s'est passé il y a trop longtemps. L'activité principale consiste à lire des logs des habitants et à interviewer de façon assez sommaire l'IA du vaisseau pour comprendre ce qui s'est passé. Et c'est tout. Mais Analogue est très bien écrit, et ce peu de choses à faire, Analogue le développe très bien.
Les logs sont bien écrits, stylés, porteurs de la personnalité des habitants, l'IA du vaisseau est bien typée et ses réparties parfaitement adaptées à l'ambiance du vaisseau : c'est très bien fichu.

Mais là où ça devient remarquable, c'est que le jeu aborde un sujet pas simple d'une manière au final assez fine.
Sans gros spoilers, le jeu va évoquer toutes les problématiques d'un problème de société lié à la discrimination.
Mais il va le faire sans gros sabots. Évoqué par les situations décrites dans les logs. Dans le ton employé par les protagonistes, y compris par l'IA, qui adapte son discours, selon ce que vous direz sur vous et votre jugement sur ce que vous lirez. C'est remarquable de justesse.

Dans ce genre de "véhicule à thèse", on aurait pu tomber sur une narration avec des gros sabots, avec une situation tire-larme (il y en a, hein) et un discours univoque pour dire "houlala ce qui se passe là c'est mal", mais non : le jeu fait le pari que vous allez vous indigner tout seul comme un grand. Le jeu évoque les paroles de protagonistes qui ont intégré et défendent leur position de victime, ou celui de la majorité approuvant le système. C'est bien fichu et çà marche. Dans l'absolu, il pourrait servir d'outil de sensibilisation intéressant...

... mais c'est aussi un jeu. Comme je le disait, l'activité ludique en tant que tel ne vole pas haut, mais elle fonctionne assez bien.
En gros vous vous activerez en :
- lisant des logs et en les soumettant à une IA, qui vous demandera sommairement votre avis dessus, et en ira de son petit commentaire
- bidouillant sur une console avec invite de commande pour gérer deux trois paramètres pour régler quelques problèmes
- faisant quelques choix "moraux" et de sympathie/antipathie, pour déterminer votre affinité avec l'IA

Le jeu comporte 5 fins. Je fais ce retour après en avoir vu une (la moins sentimentale des 5, je pense).
Une partie se boucle en 2-3 heures... et encore, sur ce premier run, j'ai pris mon temps pour bien tout lire.
L'ensemble a suffisamment titillé ma curiosité pour que j'ai envie de débloquer les autres fins.
Les graphismes sont sommaires, mais fonctionnent. Bon, comme d'hab, c'est typé manga.
Tout est en anglais (plutôt un bon niveau). La culture de référence évoquée est coréenne.
L'interface fait le job, mais auraient pu être un peu plus ergonomique. En l'état, çà n'handicape pas le jeu.
La musique a le mérite de ne pas prendre la tête mais est totalement oubliable.

Au total, vous ne jouerez pas à Analogue pour son gameplay de guedin, et sa production value à trouzmiyon de dollars.
Mais vous y jouerez peut-être pour la qualité de la délivrance de son message.
Et ce ne sera pas du temps perdu.

29573862.review:
Забавная визуальная новелла для прохождения которой используется не только мышка, но и текстовый терминал... Так себе терминал, даже «таб комплишена» в нём нет. История тут конечно не тянет на «Войну и мир», но вполне приличная, внезапно для России злободневная и про Искусственный интеллект. Собственно говоря, сборка  её по кусочкам составляет нарратив этого произведения. Если вы не владеете корейским или японским, то для вхождения во вселенную рассказа остаётся только английский. Язык не сложный, так что если технический английский для чтения доступен, то особых сложностей не будет. Тут есть элементы симулятора свиданий, но всё более-менее пристойно — только разговоры. 

В качестве движка новеллы использовался [url=https://www.renpy.org/]Ren'Py[/url] с Python «под капотом», который распространяется под свободной лицензией и, соответственно, портирован почти на всё, что движется. Поэтому не удивительно, что Ubuntu 16.04 на ноутбуке замечательно «подхватило» эту игру и проблем мной обнаружено не было.

[h1]Этот обзор входит в список [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1103944566]Игры, Linux, Steam, обзоры[/url].[/h1]

29309202.review:
The game was pretty okay. It was something fun to play once and discover the truth. But only if it's on sale. 

Pros:
The music was pretty chill and relaxing. Good reading music, since there was a lot of reading involved I approve of that. 
The world was pretty interesting, just the whole mystery of what happened at year 0. 
Reading people's personal logs was super invasive and almost like reading their diaries, I felt like a real historian. 
Technically all logs are accessible without following any search paths - if you have the logID you can read and show any log to the AI without bothering with the actual story
The console hacking phase was pretty fun and interesting
There were a few (slightly buggy) shortcuts in the ui that made it more tolerable to read

Cons:
The waifu stuff. I really, really could have done without it. A lot more tolerable if you play the game telling *Mute you're a woman, but only a little.
The AI's not having comments on stuff that I thought was worth commenting on. ("I don't know what you're looking for"). Or repeating the same thing for a lot of logs. 
The mystery of Day 0 remains (there's a sequel which really wasn't worth it)
I was much more interested (especially coming back from the sequel to this game) in what happened from Year 0 to the years which were relavant to the issue at hand. 
I wish it was all from the console ui and not from the unfun ui the game takes place in. I'm a person who hates leaving my keyboard to touch the mouse, so I wasn't pleased.

29093225.review:
[H1] << Analogue: A Hate Story / Феодальное будущее >> [/h1]

[h1] Сюжет (Warning! Возможны спойлеры): [/h1]

Новелла начинается с входящего сообщения главному герою (имя которого не называется), в котором ему поручается работа по раскрытию тайны одного космо-колониального* корабля, именуемого "Мугунхва". При неизвестных обстоятельствах, люди населявшие корабль погибли и ваша задача - узнать почему же это произошло, поэтапно собирая полную картину событий с помощью чтения логов корабля, сделанных членами влиятельных семей этого самого корабля. В расследовании вам будут помогать И.И. безопасности корабля (Мьют) и архивный И.И. (Хён Э), весьма расходящиеся во мнении о событиях, произошедших на корабле и их интерпретации.
Несмотря на то, что события на корабле явно происходили в далёком будущем, его жители жили в строю, схожим с феодальным. И как ни странно, лейтмотивом новеллы будет то, что: "Мужчины почитаемы, а женщины унижены". Основное внимание в собираемой истории приковывается к двум влиятельным семьям (Смитов и Кимов) и так называемой "Бледной невесте" - смертельно больной девочке, которую в ещё более прошлом времени поместили в стазис с надеждой, что в будущем её смогут вылечить. Но к сожалению, ожидаемое "будущее" не наступило и криокамеру варварски разбили, посчитав её "яйцом". Что же случилось с ней, да и с самим кораблём после "вылупления" вы уже узнаете сами (я же всё-таки не пересказ тут пишу:).
Отмечу также, что для меня в этой новелле не было ни одного полностью положительного персонажа и все так или иначе были с "грешком на душе". Но конечно же, это не отменяет того, что сюжет мне однозначно понравился и я остался полностью доволен.

[h1] Далее в деталях: [/h1]

Визуально, как видно по скриншотам в магазине, новелла не изобилует ни задниками ни CG (по сему, она не придётся по вкусу людям, любящим больше поглазеть, нежели почитать). Если же оценивать лишь двух персонажей, появляющихся на экране, то стоит сказать, что они неплохо нарисованы и в этом притензий быть не должно.

Музыкальное сопровождение было немного монотонным и слегка навязчивым, но лично мне надоесть не успело. Количество проигрываемых композиций я конечно не считал, но по-моему их было не так уж и много. 

Среди выбивающихся аспектов новеллы можно выделить консоль (а-ля про. хакер), взаимодействия с которой, непосредственно важны и возможные 5 концовок (что довольно немало, если брать в сравнение другие новеллы). 
По длительности чтения, новелла займёт примерно 6, 7 или 8 часов в зависимости от вашего восприятия текста.

[h1] Итог: [/h1]

Подводя итог, ещё раз хочется упомянуть, что новелла построена исключительно на чтении логов и их анализе совместно с И.И. а также выборе ответов по тому или иному прочитанному логу. Такое построение новеллы отпугивает многих, суля сущую скучу во время чтения (слегка запутанная история же этому лишь способствует). Засим многим она может поначалу банально не понравиться. Но, судя по себе могу сказать, что в процессе чтения я буквально "втянулся" в сюжет и ещё раз повторюсь, что остался им доволен. Оттого положительный отзыв и рекомендация к прочтению сей новеллы.

This is one of those games that's about talking to imaginary girls but it's not really a game, it's more like a choose your own adventure, but you're not really talking to imaginary girls, you're talking to imaginary imaginary girls because they're computer programs within a computer program within a computer program and they're representations of girls who actually existed inside the game so it's weird and Korean and kind of confusing. Even more confusing because I think it was written by a white canadian girl but whatever.

But there's this interesting thing going on in that it explores what would happen if a multi-generational space voyage had something catastrophic happen and all memories and culture from the civilization who launched the ship in the first place were more or less erased and subsequent generations had to deal with a reversion to primitive/more openly patriarchal cultural structures. It's surprisingly interesting, but I almost always have a problem with the interface on these "visual novels" and this one is no exception. It's a minor quibble and I knew what I was getting into with this so I'm not really going to fault it for that.

That said, it's not fucking around when it calls itself a visual novel. It's almost entirely comprised of reading text and occasionally running commands on a dos-like interface, so if that ain't your thing, breeze on by.

This is my first time venturing into the visual novel genre.  I mistakenly assumed that all these "games" that featured cute anime girls would all end up being weird dating sims, cheesy at best and porny at worst. 

NOT SO. This is an incredibly sad story that really sucks you in. It really hits hard too. The format of the game is really interesting, I've never experienced anything like it. It was simple, but not boring. Minimalistic, but had great depth. The writing is top notch, I think.

You know so little to begin with and piece together this awful tragedy that occured on a ship lost in space from many generations ago. Despite all the awesome reviews, I wasn't really prepared for all this. 

I've already bought and started in on the sequel, and I see myself enjoying a whole new genre that I wasn't even aware existed.

28032269.review:
If you like snooping in people's diaries and passing judgement, this could be for you. An interesting based-on-historical-real-life world hidden in a typically ludicrous 'Japanese' visual novel where anything resembling a female falls in love with you.

My biggest worry when starting this is it would have too much reading and no interactivity. Thankfully it's not a giant novel hidden within a 'game', and you get some yes/no questions that can alter things a little. These Q&As aren't done perfectly, sometimes neither choice is what you want, and things happen that you should have choice over but couldn't help, but not enough for me to be annoyed about.

I've played two of these types of games now (although this is set in some form of futuristic Korean ship rather than Japan), and am struck by the similarities. There's always one chick who's pretty, cute, subservient, likes geeky things. Then she has a sister/friend/nemesis who has an 'attitude', a kooky sense of style and is independent - the hard to get one. Yet one or both randomly and suddenly fall in love with you with equal ease despite not knowing you and it being ACTUALLY ESTABLISHED that you're a loner who is awkward in the outside world and avoids people. Oh, and the women in this game are AI, so NOT EVEN REAL OR PHYSICALLY ABLE TO INTERACT WITH YOU.

The reason I mention this is I thus fully expected this to be written by a guy who has projected himself as the main character, but actually it was written by a woman, a self-proclaimed feminist, and the main point was that it was supposed to bring awareness to the horrible things women in Korea a couple of centuries back had to live through. So I don't get why I'm wanting to bang the AI or why she felt the need to dress it up with this flirty subplot. I guess this is what these kinds of games all do, given my limited experience, but there's nothing wrong with breaking the mould.

There are some interesting mini-stories told via the diaries and emails you snoop, written well enough. So I do recommend this game if this all sounds normal to you. You're probably used to it by now. If it's your first foray into this mad world of awkward Japanophile virgins, it's worth a look too since the world there once was on this ship is kinda interesting.

The somewhat heavy storyline doesn't mean a sacrifice in "cute factor" either. There's even a fun dressup "mini game" you can play with one of the characters. Adorable! 27930117.review:
本作是让我入坑steam的契机作品，但并不是我入坑steam的第一作。[spoiler]作品以玩家，一名泛太空调查员的视角，通过对一艘失事generation ship(这词不知道用中文怎么说，世代移民船？)的调查，讲述了遥远的未来的平行宇宙中一场源于人类的恐惧而引发的社会坍圮，技术倒退，人类灭绝的一场惨剧的影响，少女的异想天开，以及关于人工智能的不解之谜“‘我’的意义何在？”[/spoiler]我本可以继续沿着前面的黑块的趋势继续从内容开始分析这个由熟悉朝鲜半岛社会文化的加拿大裔作家所讲述的曲折人心的太空幻想，但我想以steam对剧透内容粗糙的支持，若是如此下去这评测就得充满黑块以致于无法阅读了。所以我还是换个方法来写好了，对了，虽然有些晚了，这游戏完全没有中文，所以尽管只是些很口语化的文字，但如果对自己英文水平没信心的话，还是绝对不要入手的，免得到时候您埋怨我事小，写差评事中，败坏了这科幻佳作事大。

那么，比起讲述我的理解下这个科幻小说的优点和推荐理由，我要用一个情景问题来对可能感兴趣的玩家来推荐这款游戏：

假设孤独的您是等级制度森严的神权政治国家中生活的一名离经叛道者——孑然一身的冒险者，一日日常冒险中发现了一神秘山洞，内有一乳白色半透明大卵，卵内朦胧可见一奇装异服妙龄之少女，作为赌神男性的阁下会做出什么选择呢？

如果阁下愿意一直阅读文字到这儿而不是太长不看，并且还对这个情景的结局感兴趣的话，那么我认为您会对本科幻小说感兴趣的。

什么，您说这是互动电子游戏而不是什么科幻小说？啊哈，那么您是虚假宣传的受害者，因为本游戏的选项其实并不能决定结局啊，贤爱才是真正的女主角啊，mute*的故事只是个引子，想知道属于mute*的故事，请购买hate plus。

27763832.review: VNs get a lot of flak among Western audiences, but Analogue is a pretty great example of how the format could be used to its fullest extent. Even though we can only see two of the characters, they are both developed very thoroughly and present a complex and enriched story. I'm really glad the author was willing to make a story about a critical social issue and gave it the gravity it deserved, while also making a very satisfying experience to play through. If you are a fan of using science fiction to explore social issues, a fan of visual novels, or simply someone interested in trying out a new experience, please check it out!

27692095.review:
You are an interstellar investigator tasked with uncovering what befell the massive and since obliterated Korean generation ship [i]Mugunghwa[/i]. As you arrive, you're greeted and assisted by the last survivor of the tragedy; an AI who has since been lying dormant for hundreds of years with deep ties to the long departed residents.

Analogue: A Hate Story is essentially a visual novel with less visuals than novel that excels at being much more involved and gripping than most VNs I've played/read. Whether you're pulling up the terminal interface for the [i]Mugunghwa[/i] to re-balance power systems via text commands or reassuring your digital partner, your actions never really feel inconsequential.

Pair the above up with good writing, an emotional plot rife with injustice, and an interesting placement of traditional Korean customs in a SciFi setting, and you get Analogue: A Hate Story.

27106705.review:
Замечательная мрачная история о больной девушке в опустившемся до средневекового состояния обществе обитателей колонизационного космического корабля. Сюжетный твист всего один, но он переворачивает вообще всё с ног на голову. А ещё есть возможность вытащить с мёртвого корабля оба модуля ИИ, весьма нетривиальная, и я бы сам не факт что догадался бы. Зато можно сказать, что нумерация документов и поиск по их базе существует не просто так - ведь зная номера документов(из другого роута), можно спрашивать у ИИ комментарий на события, которые вовсе не представлены в доступном нам в данном роуте куске базы данных. 

Исследование куч логов скрашивает болтовня с виртуальной помошницей, с которой можно общаться в любом направлении - можно ругать или унижать, можно дружить, и даже вести романтические беседы.

Написано очень живо и интересно, плюс соприкосновение с нераспространённой корейской культурой и традициями.

26742546.review:
미연시의 새로운 길을 열어주겠다! 미연시라기보다는 스토리 텔링 게임이라하는게 더 어울리겠군요. 
한 가지 아쉬운 점이 있다면 이야기를 만들기 위해서 그렇게 한건지 아니면 게임작가가 실제로 그렇게 생각하는 것인지  조선시대 여성의 직위를 너무 낮게 보았다는 점입니다. 사람들은 잘못된 인식으로 조선시대때 여성들이 학대받고 사회적 지위가 없으며 물건으로 취급받았다고 생각하더군요,...물론 조선시대때 남존여비사상이 있던 것은 사실입니다. 하지만 위 게임에서처럼 사람을 물건 취급할정도로 대하는 것은  드물었다 하더군요(없었다고는 장담못하겠습니다. 현대사회에서도 그러한 부분은 충분히 찾아보면 보일테니까요). 실제로 고려시대때는 남존여비 사상이라기보다는 남자와 여자를 같은 사람으로 보는경향이 강했고 조선시대부터 유교사상이 강해져 남존여비라는 관념이 생기기 시작했지만 우리 조상들은 여성에게 재산 상속권을 부여하고 여성이 시집올때 여성집안의 성을 그대로 가져올정도로 여성에 대해서 예와 존중을 갖추어 대했다고 합니다. 쓸데없는 역사얘기가 길어졌는데 실제는 위와 같은 여성 천대와 핍박이 없었다고 말할수는 없겠지만 현대사회를 살아가는 우리들과 외국인들이 생각할 정도로 심하지는 않았다는게 저의 요지입니다.
게임자체는 훌륭합니다. 스토리라인과 예상외의 결과 그리고 무엇보다 이쁜 캐릭터(!) 재미있게 플레이하였습니다!

26675897.review:
Analogue: A Hate Story made me internalize how horrifying it would be to live in an extremely patriarchal society like I never have before. The personal logs detailing the lives of all these people rarely cast anyone as a straight-up villain. Most people are trying to do what's right, but their society being what it is, no one has the knowledge to want to, or power to, change it, despite the suffering and extreme rigidity of their lives. 

The way more logs are unlocked over time as you read through them with the ship AI:s is very compelling and it lends a lot of personality to the logs since the AI:s can expand upon them, or even contradict them.

I'd highly recommend Analogue: A Hate Story because of it's compelling story, intricate characters and cute AI waifus.

26666948.review: While Analogue: A Hate Story's tale is nothing to write home about. It attempts to tell it in a different way. I can recommend it on that alone.

26653746.review:
Good VN game.

Plot and gameplay are pretty simple.  You're hired to go investigate a derelict spaceship and find out what happened.  You arrive on the ship and use the terminal to activate the ship's AI.  You spend the game interacting with the AI and reading the ship logs of various families and people who were on board to find out what happened.  Reading logs and interacting with the AI causes her to unlock more ship logs.   Log entries are often given to you out of order & out of context but fill in as you discover more, so they will eventually make sense.  Some other stuff happens as well.

Couple of cons:  1. Reading some logs can be confusing due to the confusing family names not being particularly memorable.  Expect plenty of “Who's this guy/girl again” moments until you read a bit and hopefully remember who that person is.  2.  Getting 98% of the logs and finding out the one you're missing is the pronunciation log that you're pretty sure you got before.

Not a lot to say.  Enjoyed the plot and stories, enjoyed the characters, liked playing around with the terminal, and enjoyed fussing the AI's.  Looking forward to the sequel.

26365975.review:
Uma VN bem diferente do que eu estava acostumado a jogar, adorei as IA principalmente a Hyun-ae, ela é uma tsudere superfofa, já a Mute eu não gostei muito dela no início mas depois que vi seu lado mais sentimental fiquei com pena dela. A única coisa que eu me arrependo é de não ter comprado esse game antes.

Um breve resumo do enredo em si: você é um detetive/explorador que fica incumbido de investigar uma nave espacial colônia que havia desaparecido a séculos atrás, sim estamos num futuro pra lá do ano 3000 embora o jogo não nos informe ao certo a data no presente, e se possível descobrir a rasão pelo seu desaparecimento. Dentro da nave você se depara com duas simpáticas(ou nem tanto) IA de segurança que basicamente são a chave para se chegar ao fundo deste mistério.

A jogabilidade é um pouco complicada no começo pois logo de cara o game te manda um prompt de comando, mas são poucos os comandos e é tudo bem intuitivo e fácil na verdade. Apos isso você deve ler os vários documentos com as IA para que elas possam lhe fornecer informações relevantes sobre o passado da nave e seus habitantes.

26174474.review:
Holy shit, what a journey. 
I mean, the story is just so well done, the pacing is just superb. Just enough filler to keep you engaged so that when something important does come up, it feels all the more significant. The twists felt well built up to, and many of the characters felt like they had unique perspective, which is very difficult to pull off as well as Christine Love did. Really on a technical sense, there are generally very few bad things, and even those are just the smallest grammar nitpicks. 
But the story itself is amazing. I wouldn't want to spoil anything, but I only want to say that it is [i]extrordinarily[/i] tragic. Romeo and Juliet (to pull the easiest metaphor) never knew such hopelessness, I swear. The two main characters give such a different perspective from each other concerning the events that I honestly think that it just would not have worked without either one of them. 
The only issues I have are a minor bug concerning getting the 100% log completion and that it was a bit short; I passed the game in 2 sittings, 4 hours total (but I am a fast reader.) The rest of the time I spent trying to complete it without looking up walkthroughs, which did double my playtime. 
All in all though, an amazing experience that will stay with me for a long time. Seriously get this (also the soundtrack. It's definitely worth it.)

25994931.review:
[h1]Namjon yeobi[/h1]

Мрачная визуальная новелла о потерявшемся корабле с непроизносимым названием Мугунгхва.
Поднимаются в новелле такие темы как классовое неравенство и доминирование мужчин, ну, да, а что вы хотели если автор феминистка?

[b]Сюжет[/b]:
Спустя почти тысячелетие после пропажи корабля, его внезапно находит одна колония и исторический музей просит тебя узнать что собственно с ним случилось.
Собственно на корабле давным давно все умерли, действует лишь "архивный ИИ" Хён Э и ИИ безопасности Мьют.
Из логов мы узнаём что изначально корейское общество корабля из-за чего-то, что в сюжете вообще не раскрывается, деградировало в феодальное, да к тому же использующее китайское письмо! В общем по барабану, нам интересно из-за чего все умерли, в этом и состоит вся мякотка, примерно в середине прохождения раскрывается суть, но не вся, полную картину мы увидим только если доверимся Хён Э.
Итак, общество, после деградации было 2 главные семьи на судне: Смиты и Кимы.
У Кимов был артефакт, яйцо (на самом деле криокамера, ну тупые), в котором была маленькая девочка и из-за того что все неучи, они назвали её Бледная Невеста, та, которая поднимет Кимов с колен. В своё время девочку поместили в эту криокамеру в надежде что в будущем найдут лекарство от болезни.
И семья Смитов, я xз зачем её если честно описывать, если всё крутится вокруг Кимов. Ну в общем это семья всяких пьяниц, лесбиянок, типичное зажравшееся быдлo.

Общество со своими скелетами в шкафу.

[b]Геймплей[/b]:
Кроме консоли в которой мы можем повбивать команды, большую часть мы будем читать логи и разбираться что там произошло, а так же общаться с ИИ. К примеру, изначально наш герой бесполый и неизвестного возраста, так можно представиться маленькой, одинокой (или нет :D) девочкой.

[b]Музыка[/b]:
Играет тут по большей части отстранённая электроника, прям атмосфера невесомости. Самое то чтобы читать.

[b]Графика[/b]:
Ну, в целом о графке можно говорить если обратить внимание на двух ИИ. Их рисовка выполнена хорошо (Ну конечно, художник был тот же что и у Katawa Shoujo), куча эмоций, можно одеть Хён Э в красиво нарисованные костюмы.

[h1]Вывод:[/h1]
Несмотря на то, что полное прохождение занимает всего 6 часов, это не делает игру плохой, я бы сказал что автору просто было уже влом делать ещё больше логов.

10/10

25992712.review:
Analogue: A Hate Story is a visual novel unlike many others. You're presented with one objective: discover what happened to a certain ship, the Mugunghwa, through the logs of its dead crew. And of course, download said logs and get them to your employer. After all, you gotta get paid, ya' know?

But it goes deeper than that.

When I said it's unlike any others, I meant it. Unlike other VNs, you don't go to exotic locations, meet new characters, or stuff like that... all you got is a terminal. At least, at first. Because then, the cutest goddamn AI you could ever meet comes to greet you, gives you a display, and the game goes on.

And boy, does it go on.

It may seem short (Took me 6 hours to 100% the game), but I promise it will be worth your while. With an amazing. and for some people, minimalistic (even though I think it's prefectly fine that way) cast, a deep, rich storyline, moments that will make you laugh, moments that will make you cry, and moments that wil make you feel dread, and doubt your own morals and opinions you had at the start of the game... Analogue: A Hate Story is a must-have, in my opinion. It's easy to get into, REALLY easy to get hooked, and immensely satisfying to play through until the end. 

And it has a sequel, Hate Plus, so you'll be able to get even more of the amazing duo that is *Hyung-ae and *Mute!

Overall, I give this game, a 9 out of 10. It was an amazing experience, and I would certainly buy it again if I could.

What are you doing, reading this review?! If you've got a spare 10$, give this amazing VN a try!

25965888.review:
Although I had previously recommended this game on Steam, having recently finished my second full playthrough of [i]Analogue: A Hate Story[/i], I felt like I should accord it a proper review.

As an unabashed lore enthusiast, I must lead my review with praise for the world developer Christine Love created on board a generation ship lightyears into deep space. It is at once futuristic, yet historical; fantastical, yet grounded; beautiful, yet haunting. It is not the world which drew me to [i]Analogue[/i], but it is certainly what drew me [i]into[/i] it, making me want to read more and more about it, learn more about its society and people, and see it from the perspective of each and every of its inhabitants.

In many ways, it had to be what drew me in, as it will have to be what draws in anyone who plays it: unravelling the mystery of what happened on board the [i]Mugunghwa[/i] is, after all, the sole meat of the game. Fortunately, Love's talent for writing made engaging with her world an easy task, bringing it to life with skill both technical and poetic. Though the game presents the player with numerous logs, letters, transcripts, and diary entries, each stands apart from the next through the care with which it was written. Each word seems carefully and deliberately chosen to present the reader with the most information in the most concise package, painting the narrative—and everything and everyone in it—with vibrancy and depth. Love knows players will spend a lot of time reading, and she takes care to waste none of it.

Too, Love's understanding of the human psyche shines in the way [i]Analogue[/i]'s characters are brought to life. The AI constructs *Hyun-ae and *Mute, with whom the player interacts, reap the most visible benefits, and throughout the game I found myself caring for them, and empathizing with them, as though they were real. Yet even the characters we only read about in logs benefit here, each with their own unique personality and perspective. The style and tone with which each author writes reflects this, and aids the player in untangling [i]Analogue[/i]'s dense narrative.

Aside from the writing, I will also take a moment to praise the game's other perks. Isaac Schankler's beautiful soundtrack can be both catchy and poignant, and I've listened to it outside of the game countless times. [i]Analogue[/i]'s æsthetic is clean and refined in a way which puts to shame other visual novels, especially where the user interface is concerned. Finally, Love finds novel ways to utilize the Ren'Py engine's Python scripting system, and the game's sometime reliance on a command line interface certainly appealed to my inner nerd.

Although I have difficulty criticizing [i]Analogue[/i], I would be negligent if I pretended the mechanics of play lived up to the game's otherwise high standard. The foremost issue I have is the series of binary dialogue options the player must use in response to the AIs *Hyun-ae and *Mute. This is explained as a technical limitation on the part of the protagonist's computer interface with said AIs and their ship, and while this fiction might excuse the crudeness of the mechanic better than other visual novels do, it's made frustrating by the way the player's responses are framed by the game. The story's morals, while delivered skillfully and subtly by the main narrative, were regrettably let down whenever I was made to choose one of two responses, when I properly agreed with neither.

Nevertheless, this one complaint should not sour you to the plethora of good things [i]Analogue: A Hate Story[/i] has going for it. [i]Analogue[/i] is certainly my favorite video game of all time, and one I will recommend to anyone for whom it piques an interest.

A strange bird of a game

Analogue is basically a visual novel made out of datalogues.  

You are tasked with solving the mystery of what happened on a ancient spaceship, but when you actually get power working things get complicated fast.  You'll spend much of your time sifting through diary entries, trying to search for titles and words that may relate to your pursuit, and trying to juggle the chronological order of events in your head.  Also there are two computer AI's with attitdude that you'll be interacting with throughout.

There are good themes here, the game doesnt feel overly preachy, and there are multiple endings, albeit earning those endings is not very interesting in a game sense.  Not much to say about the music though.  

If you enjoy texted based mysteries, and dont mind a very limited visual tableau then you'll probably enjoy Analogue

If gratuitious reading and light game mechanics scare you off, you'll most certainly not like Analogue.

A tremendous, heart-wrenching (and at times stomach-churning) gaming experience with progressive feminist themes.
