545552.review:
If you like Text-based or Choose your own adventure stories, this is a must-play.

It explores the depravity of humanity and the extremes that they pursue when they're stranded in deep space.

You play the role of a detective on contract to find out what happened aboard a Korean Vessel sent on a mission to colonize other planets. Your ultimate goal is to download any of the ship's logs as well as any active AI before you depart. You find you can't do this because it's requesting a super admin pasword, which you don't have.

After figuring out how to activate the ship's AI, she talks to you and starts to show you some of the ship's logs. At first, it starts off very dull, throwing out a ton of names that you can hardly recognize, but as you start to progress through the logs you're eventually tipped off on what the password is. As you keep reading you start to find some pretty disturbing stuff, and when you're introduced to the ship's other AI, that's when things get interesting.

If you are interested, play this first, then play Hate Plus if you want to learn more. Just remember: There is a way to save both AI's, even though a series of events lead you to believing it's not true.

4354512.review:
Okay, I can't NOT recommend this VN anymore. (Visual Novel) Note the term is Visual Novel, meaning the focus is intensely on the story and not gameplay. If you enjoy a good mature read, and/or anime girls in cosplay... (xD) Then you'll easily love this VN. The writing is fantastic, Christine Love is a brlliant writer of Tragedy. Yup, this is a Tragedy as defined by drama. It's rare to find a gameworld that draws me in and engrosses me as much as "Analogue: A Hate Story" and it's sequal "Hate Plus" encouraging multiple playthroughs to simply uncover the whole of each story within. Lots of pebbles and a few rocks are thrown at the forth wall without shattering it, it's as much funny tongue in cheek as it is serious "Trigger."

WARNING: As said. Trigger. Massive trigger. If you have "had a tramatizing experience with" or "deeply rooted values against" the following; homosexuality, rape, depression, suicide, and overall prejudiced bullshit, then read and enjoy this with a close friend. This game/series can be a massive trigger if it blindsides you with it's content. The subject matter is as mature as it gets and still handles it with tact and feels.

HIghly recommended (For Mature audiences)

1038197.review:
I think I can count on my cat's remaining legs the number of times a I've played a game and felt such a powerful emotional and psychological attachment to the story and characters where I found myself  so deeply invested in every single moment . They felt so, so alive...even though you know from the start that everyone on board the ship has been dead for centuries. Analogue will rip at your heartstrings in one moment, then make you fall out of your chair laughing in another. It will force you to make decisions you will hate yourself for, and then console you immediately afterwards. This game invites YOU to become the author of your own narrative and as you slowly begin to uncover the truth of the Mugunghwa and her crew, you may find yourself doing some soul searching of your own.

It should also be said that Isaac Schankler's musical tracks do a superb job of complementing the pace and mood of this game, probably one of the few game soundtracks I've bought rather than downloaded off of youtube.

10/10
Simple, elegant, profound, Analogue: A Hate Story is a game that transcends any attempt to categorize or explain the experience of playing it. Love it, hate it, or dismiss it, it is a game that redefines gaming on it's own terms.

Analogue: A Hate Story is a visual novel which puts you in the shoes of an hacker trying to download the records of a strane spaceship, the Mugunghwa. The main meat of the game is to read log after log and try to have various conversations with the two AIs, *Hyun-ae and *Mute.

Unlike other visual novels, the main focus is not to get either one of the two AIs, but rather explore the story of the people on the Mugunghwa. Analogue offers different endings, which are kind of challenging to get without some input first.

There is also an unexpected timed mission in the middle of the story that can be impossible to clear without knowing which commands to use on the main computer.

Beside, Analogue: A Hate Story is a charming title, with a more than passable story and a clean, pleasant graphic presentation

1800447.review:
Analogue A Hate Story is a visual novel that puts the player, a space investigator lone wolf, to check a long lost ship that has recently resufraced - the Mugunghwa.

The game has very limited gameplay, but that is to be expected from a visual novel - it is akin to having a story told to you with some binary choices in between. The game does, however, present itself in a different manner - the player must access archives that are slowly unlocked in order to learn more about the ship's sordid past, and what lead to its eventual dereliction. You do this with your sidekick AI partner *Hyun-ae.

I cannot comment on the story for fear of spoilers, as this game is very story-centric indeed. However, I will say this - I found it to be a strong, solid tale of a retrogade society diving into its demise. It has a good couple of side stories as well, but the main arc is where all the meat is at. You also have a second AI partner who you encounter (or not) after a certain point.

Overall, I feel that Analogue manages to vary the visual novel platform enough to attract people that would otherwise not liken the visual novel structure. It has a strong story, excellent art assets, and a solid, yet limited, soundtrack. Do check it out.

4810857.review:
Analogue: A Hate Story takes place in the 26th century, where the universe is run by the Saeju Colony Historical Society. Dispatch Control sends their secret black ops team to do their dirty work, the Mugunghwa security team, led by *Hyun-ae. Following Dispatch Control's orders and assassinating those whom they believe are criminals, Mugunghwa security kill a man known as Emperor Ryu, but soon discover he was a civilian reporter, documenting civilian deaths caused by Mugunghwa security. *Hyun-ae and his team realize they have been duped by Dispatch Control and desert, becoming space pirates on the run from Dispatch Control's forces.
Ten years later, *Hyun-ae drunkenly attacks Dispatch Control's battlecruiser, the salvage ship from the beginning of the game, while near the ship of Mugunghwa. *Hyun-ae rams the salvage ship from the beginning of the game, hoping to gain revenge on Dispatch Control. The ships collide, forcing both to crash land on the hull of Mugunghwa. One of *Hyun-ae's men, *Mute, is critically wounded in the crash and *Hyun-ae is forced to find an energy cell to drive the ship's medical equipment. On the ship, a former popular tropical-like resort destination, the population has mutated into feral tribes and carnivorous plants. *Hyun-ae fights through to one of the salvage ship from the beginning of the game's escape pods, and retrieves the escape pod's energy cell, as well as an "instinct leash." The leash, when worn, begins to provide him strange tactile information, such as points for each enemy he kills.
*Hyun-ae returns with the cell, and while *Mute is under operation, the mutants attack their ship, leaving *Mute a disfigured cyborg. *Hyun-ae and *Mute, the only survivors, decide to work together to get off the ship, despite *Mute's disapproval of *Hyun-ae's thirst for revenge. The instinct leash leads *Hyun-ae to another escape pod, where they find a UNIX command-line terminal, a salvage ship from the beginning of the game security soldier who agrees to work with *Hyun-ae and *Mute, but only after they rescue Dispatch Control. As they battle through the ravaged city, a UNIX command-line terminal explains that Mugunghwa has been used by salvage ship from the beginning of the game security as a sort of training grounds, with the instinct leashes the soldiers wear as a means of ranking those within the test; those that scored kills would be the only ones that could get ammunition and other supplies to survive. When *Hyun-ae learns that a UNIX command-line terminal was Emperor Ryu's daughter, he tells her that Dispatch Control was responsible for her father's death, but claims he does not know who actually killed him.
The three make their way to the top of a skyscraper where Dispatch Control's pod landed. a UNIX command-line terminal accuses Dispatch Control of her father's death, but he simply pushes her off the side of the building. Dispatch Control then warns *Hyun-ae and *Mute that there is an armed "DNA bomb" on the salvage ship from the beginning of the game that will wipe out all life on the ship, and they must go and disarm it, as his rescue ship will not arrive in time. As they travel underground, Dispatch Control explains that prison convicts were used as the labor force to maintain the ship; they rebelled when toxic byproducts, created by the ship's solar radiation shields, were dumped in the underground prison. The convicts destroyed the shields, exposing the entire population to mutating radiation.
Aboard the salvage ship from the beginning of the game, Dispatch Control tricks *Hyun-ae and *Mute into arming what was actually an inert bomb, and leaves them to die. As fire breaks out aboard the fallen ship, the two are saved by a UNIX command-line terminal, who survived the fall by catching a power line on her way down.

1820537.review: Christine Love builds an amazing dystopian space detective story with two lovely AI characters that really get inside your head.  There are dialogue choices to be made to break up the investigation and parts of the game become very socially intiment as you have questions presented to you that ask how much you are part of the problem or how much you are willing to forgive.  Yes, the game is essentially nothing but reading datalogs and talking to AI but if you love detective stories then you'll be enthralled by the search that you need to put into the game to find all the clues to put together what exactly happened to this ship.  The truth is pretty messed up.

4016813.review:
This game may be short, but it packs a lot into that amount of time.  I think the most amazing part of Analogue is the fact that I spent the entire game willing to believe that I was in fact dealing with a derilict space ship's computer.  Everything from the AI interface all the was back down to the cmd prompt style overrider terminal seemed authentic - like a viable interface.  Even some of the incongruent behavior of the AI Hyun-ae is explained away, but to go further in would be a spoiler and a disservice to any potential player.

At first I was just trying to dig for the ship's admin password, but before long I wanted to know what happened to the inhabitants of this doomed colony ship - and I'm excited to learn more about the ship's history in the upcoming Hate Plus.

This is one of the better visual novels I've explored (and the most interactive) and by far the most immersive.  To anyone seeking a good sci-fi or general lost-history mystery, I must fully recommend Analogue: A Hate Story.

6079056.review:
Lets keep this short, and ill try to focus on some things. This is a VN of sorts, but instead of classic VN style, its stylized as a computer within a game, within your computer. Its an interesting twist that ends up working well, as your job is to read old stories and present them to the AI characters. 

Which brings up the overall plot of the game, and what the ending is like. As I said, it is like a VN, so there are multiple endings, depending on which character you choose, and there are good and bad endings as well. I counted five or so different ones I think, so plently of variety. Story wise, it is very deep and complex, following the patriarchial ways of an old family, and uncovering what caused them to go downhill. It is a very dark tale, one frought with passion, and deception. Very well written.

As for length, a single playthrougth could take an hour to complete at minimum, or near 5 hours for each log to be collected and examined. Which is not bad, but is not good either, the main enjoyment comes from reading the stories of the past people and what caused their ultimate downfall.

Those are the only things I can not as of now that I have a problem with, but for a video review that I would say sums up my thoughts on the game, see here: 
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mecz9Xxf0SM

I would recommend it to anyone who like anume, is into reading stories, and gossip as well as intiguing plot twists and information.

1242462.review:
Fascinating concept, unfortunately mediocre execution. Worth a look if on sale.

The main issue is that the writer is simply not good enough. The main writing in the logs especially shows this, being full of correspondences that feel fake or forced. There is a severe lack of tangible continuity in the story, while at the same time, despite being composed of mostly discrete chunks of narrative, it fails to achieve the breadth and depth to evoke a greater mystery.

The art is simple and limited, but effective. If not for the main writing flaws, it would be quite passable. WIth them, the simple style ultimately reinforces the limited ability to properly tell the story, as additional art could have smoothed certain flaws and enhanced the feeling of discovery.

The few puzzle elements were neat and fun, but far too restricted in scope.

Finally, the low-key but non-critical references to common Visual Novel traits unfortunately undermined the core thematics somewhat.

10년 가까이 앓아온 만성 두통과 만성 현기증 때문에 '속독' 어빌리티를 잃어 제대로 클리어하는데 지나치게 오랜 시간이 걸렸다.

양인들은 가톨릭 종교 특성상 결혼은 항상 1:1로 짝을 맞춰야만 했고, 양인들이 보던 시점에서 일부다처제를 허용하던 한국의 남존여비 사상은 매우 꺼림찍해보였을 것이다. 
그렇다해도 작품에서 너무 지나치게 묘사하는 감이 없지 않아 있긴 했다만 사실은 사실이니만큼 이에 대해 뭐라 반론할만한 명분은 찾지 않는게 바람직하다 생각된다.

이러한 비주얼 노벨 특성상 사소한 부분에서 혹평을 듣기 쉽다. 다만 화자가 전달하려는 본질이 무엇인지 파악하려 하지 않은채, 사소한 것을 물고 늘어지면서 그것을 그저 깎아내려고만 한다고 해서 그러한 행동이 자신의 수준이나 가치를 높여주진 않는다.

흔히들 줄여서 '나무를 보지 말고 숲을 보아라'라고 하는 것처럼 선입견과 우리겨레에 만연한 국수주의를 내려놓고 감상한다면 나쁘지 않을 작품이다.

1459789.review:
Wow. For being a visual novel, Analogue managed to scare me quite a bit. It forces you to make decisions far before you're ready to face consequences, and it turned 'puzzle solving' into 'let's cause a moral dilemma'.

An excellent game roughly a little longer than a movie. Moderate replay value.

6124854.review:
Analogue: A Hate Story is a peculiar beast. It's not really a game but more like an interactive story. To The Moon can be considered as an interactive story as well but compared to Analogue, they are much different. Analogue is known as a 'visual novel'. A story that uses music, artwork and animations (although very few) to move the story along. In other words, you don't really do anything. You don't jump, shoot or hit things with a crowbar. All you do is point, click and read. If you find that frustrating, then this definitely isn't for you.

Analogue can be deemed as a horror story but it doesn't deal with blood, monsters or zombies. It takes themes like biogtry and misogyny and really digs deep into those themes to showcase the disasterous effect it has on a society. What's interesting is that the story based upon old Korean society. However, the story is not always intense. There are some comedic moments and such. The story is an engrossing one and really pulls you in once you get into it. It's short but that's okay since I feel this is a game you can enjoy on a saturday afternoon. If you like to read, enjoy looking at cute anime girls or enjoying an engrossing story on corrupt society, then give this a try.

650095.review:
I'm not sure exaclty what to say about this, other than it is fantastic. Christine Love has delivered again with this remarkable work on technology, feminism, relationships and the human condition. I found myself glued to my seat as I poured through the logs. As I started to piece together what had happened in my head, each new log was absoultely tantalising yet terrifying.

If I were to compare it to another game (That's not be the same author - Digital: A Love Story is too obvious a comparison), I'd have to pick The Stanley Parable. Both have you sitting back and thinking after your first play through, both invite you to start again and see what else is in there that you missed, and both are shining examples of how stories change depending on your medium. This tale needed to be in this interactive format and shines as a result.

On top of all this, the game is startlingly well researched. The whole thing feels like an interactive, sci-fi, ghost story by Margret Atwood. The parallels with The Handmaid's Tale are obvious, but executed differently enough to remain though-provoking and ineresting.

Really, if any of the above catches your attention, give it a look.

87532.review: Quite possibly the best social examination disguised as a game I have ever played.

1985667.review:
Analogue: A Hate Story is an interactive novel where you have to find out why a spaceship filled with colonists is now floating in space devoid of life. (The name is a play on a previous game, Digital: A Love Story.) As you read the various logs, you also discuss them with the ship's two AIs to get the full picture.

(This is all from the early part of the story to avoid spoilers. If you don't want to see story, skip this paragraph.) The story that unravels revolves around a sick young girl in a culture much like modern Korea who is placed in a stasis pod in hopes that future technology can cure her. She is instead woken up far in the future where culture has actually regressed several centuries, and not only can they not cure her, but they instantly arrange a marriage against her will to gain status for the family.

This is a very sad story, but powerful and worth reading. It's not for kids, though.

There's not a ton of gameplay here to judge. The music is pretty nice, and the soundtrack isn't a bad purchase. Ultimately, the value of this game hangs entirely on its story, and if you're not interested in reading it, then this game has nothing for you. If you're okay with delving into the story for a few hours, then you may find a lot to enjoy. It's definitely worth getting on sale if it sounds interesting to you.

3445083.review: Easy to slip into, BGM fits very well, easy starting point for new people to visual novels and quite good, I have played 7 hours almost straight and still not bored, mind you I have also beaten it a few times in that time span but I skipped all the text i could after the 2nd playthrough. All in all great gamu would buy again, will play again, *Hyun-ae is best and *Mute is 2nd best, as always, hand is 3rd best.

1089013.review:
This 'game' is often described as a visual/interactive novel, which I find fairly accurate.  It's written by a Canadian author named Christine Love and puts you in the role of an investigator sifting through the logs of a long-missing colony spaceship that's recently reappeared.

Journals, transcripts, letters - primary document-type stuff for those of you who paid attention in history class - provide fragmented glimpses that slowly come together to make a full picture from many different sides.  You're not alone; the ship's two AI constructs guide you through and connect you to the world with their experiences and opinions - and connect with you via your own opinions.

When I started noticing the parallels to a certain historical topic (I'll put exactly what as a comment; mild spoilers), I was indeed reminded of a particular year of history class in school, and the further I delved into the records, the more I fell in love with and was horrified by their backwards portrayal of future and past.

Don't be fooled by the appearance of the characters - this is a mature story that deals with some heavy topics.  It's got multiple endings by way of interaction with the vessel's two AIs, which represent opposite opinions on some of the story's central themes.  You don't need to like science fiction or history - all you need is to not be afraid to read.

Analogue: A Hate Story is unique and definitely worth your time.

1644033.review: It's a visual novel, so be prepared for a LOT of reading. What's there to read is actually pretty good, even if it's at time difficult to keep track of all the different names. It's also fairly short at around 4 hours (whether this is a good length or not depends on your patience for this genre). Overall, I quite enjoyed it, despite being confused more than a few times, particularly regarding some of the more obscure achievements.

462700.review:
My first visual novel, and I fell in love. Despite a cheesy, sci-fi setting, everything in this game feels close to home, with much of its plot pulled off of historical oppression. 

When you open this game, you play it until it's done--roughly 3 hours later. You'll likely feel some regret, too, regarding ill-made decisions made from ignorance as an unseen timer counts down, giving good reason for replaying.

You only do a few things throughout the three hours; most of it's spent reading historical logs on a space ship that suffered a catastrophic event (as well as a loss of species fitness!) leaving its ignorant crew wiped out in an instant.  You also chat with two lovable AIs and input a couple computer commands as you search for the truth, which you may or may not get your first time through.

1626073.review:
In many ways it's opposed to what I valued in games as a visual novel, but, among many other things, it has me reconsider those values. The writing, as it must be, is great and the storytelling equally so. The interface is, of course, limited but never feels restrictive.

Its a wonderful game that involved me more emotionally than most other games I've played, which spend hours on getting you to be invested in your character and building an involving plot. Perhaps the strongest indication of the quality of its narrative is that your only declared goal is to get in, download, and get out, but within minutes I had ceased to care about that entirely and spent hours past what I needed to accomplish that. While many game spend their entire time trying to hook you into their central plots, Analogue effortlessly drew me into its narrative and I was not content to leave until I had thoroughly probed the depths of the Mugunghwa uncovered her story. Only then did I, could I choose to leave and I did so completely satisfied.

3508668.review: A well-written and thought-provoking visual novel about the fate of a failed generation ship, told through letters and log entries of some of its inhabitants. 575646.review:
A good story, with a nod to old tech interfaces (DOS), along with a slight detective feel and anime-styled art. There are cute anime chicks involved, as well as the ability to choose chat options with them in between reading.  

In this story, you are a solo space traveler on an apparent contract job. (No you don't get to fly the ship.) Your job is to find out what happened to an old asian colony ship. With the help of the old ships AI(s), you have to dig up as much information on what happened to the crew through reading logs and eventually download the information for your client. While reading logs, the AI will ask you about what you read, or make a statement about the character(s) or problems involved with the entry, allowing you to get a bit more insight as to what happened. This gives a unique environment where you feel as if you are reading along side an AI, and can at times really get into the story.

It does not take long to get through the game, but expect a ton of reading. Purely a virtual novel at heart, but with a 'choose your own story' ending, thus creating a much more interactive environment than other VNs like the Sakura Paradise game (Where you really have no control over the game besides watch and hit next).

This story has a very large dose of maltreatment of the sexes... specificly the fairer sex, and points towards cultures that used to, and still do, treat them very poorly. The game is rather obvious fairly quickly in showing their agenda to create a sense of oppression which may be quite real in the world, may still be unwelcome to some players. So you have been warned if that is of little or no interest to you.

After the game is done, there is little replay value besides getting the achievements, all the endings, and/or all the entries, yet the game does give you a feeling of completion and does not leave you 'in the dark' about anything, aside for what happens to your character and the AI after the game ends... but that is what the sequel is for.

Hope this review helped some of you make a decision on this game~

6357094.review: The best fusion of romance, sci-fi, and the sociological ramifications of the patriarchal constraints during the medieval Korean Joseon Dynasty.

4385798.review:
Another unique gaming experience on my list.  Analogue plays like an interactive novel.  You read log entries on a computer and show them to the two AIs that reside in the ship's mainframe.  Multiple endings promote replayability and the deeper mystery of the story is engrossing enough for the time you play the game.  There is also a "hacking" segment that involves imputting commands on a terminal, which is fun and provides a sense of urgency during a segment of gameplay.

Pros:

Unique gaming experience
Decent/engaging story
Multiple endings

Cons:

Terminal doesn't feel like a real terminal
Completely story based

The game is short, but with this style of game I'd consider that more a strength as some experiences are only meant to be a few hours long.  Pick it up on sale. B+

749118.review: I usually hate these kinds of adventures.  Thanks to some clever writing, an engaging story, and a neat little bit of hacking required halfway through the game, you're dragged back into the story way after you should've gone to bed!  It plays a little too much like a dating sim after you solve the mystery at the end, but aside from this small nitpick the rest of the game is brilliant.  I finished it in about six hours, but that's probably because I was taking notes to follow the story as you go back and forth  through email logs of the long dead crew with the help of a slightly mental AI.  I have to say the ending saddened me, although I tend to feel empathy towards the characters I interact with in good games, and this definitely qualifies.

6251769.review:
An extremely underrated gym by all accounts. Even as a lover of VN's the poor reviews this game has received in many outlets kept me for getting it until the sale. This was a mistake on my part, and one I'd suggest you don't make. Now let me iterate that if you have no love for the VN medium then this certainly won't change your mind, but for fans who know the genre it's an unexpected treat.

Got to say the "bad" first, even though it did not bug me. Small funding shows through in a sparse (if still well designed) layout, no true CG's or indeed any real imagery beyond the characters. And it does rank on the short side.

The good? Everything else. This is a masterfully written tale that transcends being simply "good" into the truly thought provoking. The world is unique, and when it’s over you may still not know how you should feel about it all, with tons of material to ponder, and possible viewpoints to take.

I cannot stress enough how much any fan of the VN medium needs to play this.

3708733.review: For those of you who have played Digital, you already have some idea of what you're getting yourself into. For those who haven't, be prepared for a beautifully-written, heart-wrenching tale that subtly draws you in via its interface, pacing, and characters. Also, go play Digital. Analogue is, on the surface, a story of a person sent to investigate a derelict spaceship. But that's not right. It's a story of two AIs, the only remaining residents of the ship. But that's not right, either. It's a story of history, of cultural differences, of secrets and questions and unexpected answers. Most of the game is reading, and it can be daunting at first. The initial selection of documents you're given are, admittedly, the least interesting. But stick with it, and you shall be rewarded for your perseverance. Although there are five endings, the nature of the game makes replayability rather low - but it might be worth skimming past the early parts again in order to unlock different documents later on and get a different angle on the story. There are only two real puzzles in the game, and both involve a command prompt interface which I found to be quite fun to use - especially in the delicious second puzzle, much later in the game. If you're not good with computers and reasoning, you might not do so well with that one, but give it a shot anyways. One speed bump is a small price to pay for an overall enriching experience.

5087780.review: Brilliant game, great story.  Short, but that's only a complaint because I liked it so much I wanted more.

2310714.review: This game is basically a VN but it tells quite an interesting story despite being a short game.

3613104.review: Masterful storytelling is something you want in a visual novel, and Analogue delivers on a chilling premise. Definitely recommended if you're a fan. Don't forget to look into Christine Love's other works; most of them are free to enjoy.

2324473.review:
チョンゲーに見えますが、このゲームはカナダ人が作ったそうです。
このゲームのすごい点は内容ではなく（内容も悪くないが）、純粋なアドベンチャーゲームがSTEAMで販売されたということです。なぜならVALVE的にはADVはゲームではなく電子書籍の範疇であったからです。
しかしこのゲームでその前例を打ち破ってくれました。これから日本製のADV（美少女ゲームとか）が販売されてもおかしくないという状況になったわけです。実際最近Cherry Tree High Comedy Clubという日本の同人ADVゲームが発売されています。

5585719.review:
If you like reading, and you enjoy intertwining little facts and pieces together, you're going to love this game. 

A spectacularly complex story that revolves around a relatively interesting storyline, Analogue will make you laugh, cry, and blush. The choices you make determine how the characters treat you, so be careful. Or not. 

There are some fast-paced segments as well to keep you on the edge of your seat. Be sure to expect those. 

I do NOT recommend this game to anyone who:
- Hates reading
- Does not like complex stories
- Has the attention span of a chickadee
- Does not like going back and forth between facts

Overall, this game - to the right person - is amazing. 

Just two more things: 
 - Have Dictionary.com in the backgroud while you play
 - Constantly save your spot.

Simple dialogue choices allow you to express your interpretations of the events, and are met with emotional responses. This game isn't for everybody, and I was even turned off at first; but as I played it, I became engaged with the story and couldn't stop. Completed the game in about 3 hours and only achieved a 70% completion. There are multiple endings available, and some additional dialogue if you like multiple play-throughs.

If you're down with visual novels/things that focus way more on story over any sort of gameplay, this is rather good. It's set on a generational colony ship in the far future...after everything failed in a huge disaster and society eventually reverted to several centuries behind where we currently are now. In particular, it explores the social structure of the Joseon Dynasty of Korea...in space. Yes, really. And plenty of moral ambiguity and some fairly dark/gruesome subject matter depending on what you manage to dig up. It's not exactly the feel-good game of the year, but some stuff in it might make you think.

See also: "Digital: A Love Story" and "don't take it personally, babe, it's just not your story", Christine Love's previous games/VNs, which are both also pretty good and both free.

830631.review:
This game is a visual novel.  If you have no idea what a visual novel is, it is essentially a Japanese-style porn game without the porn.  What you have left is a heaping supply of writing, well-translated from Korean, and a mystery that you can uncover by reading it all.

There's some game elements to it in that what you read can be shown to your AI companion to unlock more things to read.  Plus a pseudo terminal in which you type in commands that will help you unlock more things to read.

There's not much game here and you're better off with the far more fascinating predecessor which is free on the Internet.  The predecessor is called Digital: A Love Story (and it will remind you why dialing into BBS systems was a bitch).

Ultimately, there's not much here, but it can be an interesting distraction for those who like art games like Dear Esther or Home.  This game is not like either of them.

1091214.review: Not so much a game as a Visual novel, Analogue puts you in the shoes of an investigator that's been tasked to collect data entries from a colony ship once thought lost. The main plot throughout Analogue is a deconstruction of the pro-verbial "fish out of water" idea, with the female protaganist being awakened out of cyrostasis into an extremely misognistic culture. The tales told are very gripping, and based on cultural values and traditions upheld during the Joseon-era of Korean history. The novel is short (I completed it in 5 hours during my first playthrough), but there are multiple endings, and the overall quality of the narratives make Analogue: A Hate Story well worth its price.

3633867.review:
Analogue is a visual novel with a few sprinklings of Adventure game added for good measure. That means that the majority of your time playing this game will be spent reading. Having said this, the game is absolutely fantastic. The writing is superb and delivers both interesting characters and a fully-realized world. The anime visuals look great and the fully diegetic layout (coupled with a nice soundtrack) does a great job of really immersing the player.

There are a couple of genuinely shocking moments in the game, but they don't feel gratuitous and actually make for some really emotional moments. I can say without hyperbole that this was one of a very few games that has made me cry.

A word of warning, the game may be inappropriate for younger gamers, but that's for parents to decide, not me (you know your kids). Play it and decide for yourself (it's only a 2-3 hours).

If you like this, check out Digital: a Love story, an excellent (free) game by the same person.

This game is a great storytelling experience.
While innately simple, the game gives the player the role of slowly unveiling the mystery
surrounding a massive derelict colonial spacecraft, the Mugunghwa, set adrift
for almost a thousand years and all but forgotten by time,
using only the logs stored on the ship by it's former inhabitants
and the aid of the AI that reside within.

The game features a great soundtrack an intriguing and dark story dealing with moral ambiguity, transhumanism and loneliness with fleshed out characters
and high levels of character development

The game does fall into some traditions of the genre but manages to do so with care and without distorting the experience.

A definate buy for fans of light novels and beyond.

2712260.review:
Christine Love does very interesting games, although they're more like Interactive Fiction than a 'game' - she uses the medium to tell stories that wouldn't really be possible without them. Analogue is something of a companion story to Digital: A Love Story, one of her earlier works.

I really like Analogue. It is simple and basically consists of a lot of reading with a few simple puzzles to spice things up. It won't be for everyone but, really, you should try this game. It's a solid story that really tugged at my heartstrings. And the music is quite good as well.

Get it. It's a touching story that should be read.

6082419.review:
Ok so it's been like a hundred years since I played this, but now I have a firm opinion on it.

Even Digital: A Love Story showed hints of a game designer that knows so well how her interface works and what's the player relationship with it that she can predict your desperation when it fails - deliberately. Everything in Analogue is made so that you get used to, addicted to even, knowing more about the setting and the characters. As a game, Analogue teases you, makes you care about Hyun-ae with the sheer force of its information flux. It hides and shows and you want to unfold the mysteries even if you're not particularly attached to them. This is Christine Love strongest point.

This is, however and of course, her biggest shortcoming.

Every choice is a moral dichotomy and a very obvious one at that. *Mute is not a character you can relate to. She was not made to be relatable, I suppose... she's more like a storytelling prop. Analogue asks you if you think women are inferior and, if you're sane, you'll say no. Choices inevitably lead to Hyun-ae. The only way to get *Mute's route - if we should call it that way - is through a conscious, rational effort. But this is when the string behind the puppet appear and you play the game knowing its rules, doing things because you need to and not because you want to. So there's depth to the game, but you don't submerge. Instead, you're given a sonar.

1538016.review: I'm not a fan of the visual novel genre, so I honestly didn't know what to expect going into Analogue. What I found was a chill experience filled with a delicate balance of mystery, humor, and horror. Analogue is a layered experience that you can finish in an afternoon and be haunted by for a week. Issac Schenkler's soundtrack is a perfect complement to the playing experience and I strongly recommend purchasing it as well.

I was a bit leery of the whole 'visual novel' aspect of the game, but after receiving it as part of an indie bundle, I decided to try it out. While rather short - about five hours - I thoroughly enjoyed it. It gets rather emotional, and even more so if you allow yourself to be immersed into the setting. It took me a while to make sense of everything - probably about half an hour - but once you understand who all of the major players are, and start to grasp the setting, things really get awesome.

Sadly, the emotional impact was diminished quite a bit whilst trying to achieve the alternate endings. Going over documents I had already read just wasn't quite as stimulating as the first time, although ocassionally I'd stumble over new content that would make me laugh (or cry, as it were). 

Anyway, if you like the concept of video games as art, I think you'll absolutely love this game. If you expect any sort of action, then look elsewhere. This game is very slow-paced (as it should be).

The first VN on Steam, and boy is it a good one. 

You play as a Freelanser of sorts and get contracted to investigate what happened in Mugunghwa a Colonial Spaceship which suddenly dissapared 400 years ago, and has drifted in a rarely visited place in space ever since.

When you hack into the ship, you encounter *Hyun-ae, a AI which will help you by providing logs and other relevant info in your quest to find out what REALLY happened.

1114028.review:
Analogue is a lovely little sci-fi JRPG which has you tap into a long forgotten system and discover the depths of the secets hiding within.

I played this game a long time ago, completing 1 playthrough, which took roughly 3 hours. The game is a roleplaying game, and provides little action events, and is moreso built on storybuilding through narrative and text (ie there's quite a bit of reading). But, that isn't a bad thing, and works really well in the environment sculpted in the game.

Insightful, dark and comedic at times, the game hits a number of topics which are not usually seen in games of this sort. If you're the patient sort, and you feel this would be your type of game, it probably will be. But don't expect Die Hard 5; expect a well written story told in an enjoyable environment, with dynamic and vivid characters.

There's replayability here too. Each event has multiple "endings", so you can re-do your story and play from different angles!

Check it out!

-Nilesy

This game gets a lot of unneeded flak, and I can see why: the visual novel genre isn't for everyone. At its core, this game is basically a novel that has a pretty interface and an interactive narrator, that once you read everything available, you have to do a little bit of thinking and some work to get to the next part. There are also some REALLY clever puzzles in this game, including one that involves creating a paradox to achieve an ending that would otherwise be impossible.

If the words Ever17, Corpse Party, Collage, and 999 conjure positive images for you, then you will love this game.

If you've never played a Visual Novel before, there's a demo.

As for me, I think Steam needs to get some more Visual Novels.

Analogue is like a digital book. There are a few images here and there (the images consist of two different AI characters, both show different emotions during the story), but other than that it's all text. And at times the player is asked to use some sort of command prompt. It's all fairly basic, but if you've never worked with command prompts it can be a bit tricky I guess, especially since there's a time based event later on in the 'game'. 
Like I said, there's a whole lot of reading. In daily life I rarely read so it took a bit of adjusting for me. It can be boring at times, even though the story is solid. Just don't go and expect a proper 'game' here. It isn't anything like that. But if you like a good read I suggest you give this a try. You might just be surprised. I wouldn't really recommend it to anyone else though.

[Rating: 70/100]

2544634.review:
An indie game that relies on text to communicate it's story. You play a hacker assigned to retrieve data from a vessel that went missing centuries ago. It makes you feel like you're a hacker in a old computer system, trawling through files and occasionally figuring out puzzles. 

It also has roleplaying elements as you are forced to interact with the ship's AI personalities whilst discovering (through questioning and reading) what happened on the ship. If you're a fan of anime and asian culture (specifically Korean? I think) then the depth the story takes you will be fascinating, if you're not as interested then you'll get tired of it pretty quick.

Upside, it's cheap and it's really short. There are multiple endings and the game has a deep story, if you're interested. If none of this sounds appealing, or if reading large slabs of text on screen troubles you, avoid this game.

6042512.review:
I honestly cannot find the words to describe this game in a sentence or two. I can, however, tell you it is a great story about an isolated society that practically drove itself into the ground before it was actually eradicated. I became so attached to the story, I had to complete it in one sitting because I just had to know more. It brings up questions of morality and emotions as you progress in almost any way you wish. Your interactions with the AIs can influence how this seemingly simple mission will end. The only problem I will ever have with this game is the rather large amount of questions left unanswered regarding what all happened on that ship, but I feel content with what I did learn. This is the kind of game I could play over and over again, despite how many times I end up doing what I've done before, and still enjoy every minute of it. There, that's the best I could do to show how much I love this game.

No spoilers, but I offer this advice: you have 16 save slots. Use them.

5179941.review:
As a start, I'd say this VN (Visual Novel) has a nicely woven story for you to enjoy. It gets darker and edgier and it may not be everyone's cup of tea, but if you like a clever plot filled with intrigues, scandals, and backstabbings, then you should give this a chance.

The outset might scare you off with a somewhat vague and abstract intro. You're required to download logs left behind by the deceased crews of a spaceship and put them together to find out what happened. If you're willing to do just that, it will all makes sense in the end and gives a rewarding experience for you.

Don't let the animesque designs put you off. If you think this is some petty waifu simulator game for weeaboos, then you're painfully mistaken. You'll be too busy getting engrossed with the story. There IS a romance feature, but consider them as a bonus, since the main focus of the game is not about getting a virtual girlfriend for you; if you want those kind of VNs, look somewhere else.

292574.review:
An engaging interactive story. Plot is reminiscent of Taiwanese/Korean period dramas.

Characterisation of the main roles are almost immaculately conceived as with their individual motivations; the ending moments being quite hard-hitting. Note that the tale does include somewhat explicit/graphic descriptions at certain points. 

A successful playthrough should last around 2-3 hours and much of the gameplay primarily involves heavy reading. The title also involves understanding of a pseudo command prompt that is not particularly too obtuse to grasp for most players.

Be sure to also download and try out a free copy of the developer's previous work, Digital: A Love Story.

It goes by fast; a few endings in a couple of hours, but worth picking up if it's under ten bucks. Christine Love is nutty as hell... but credit where it's due: The woman can write. The level of characterization in this game is wonderful, as well as the blending of various themes (some of which she's known for in her other games. Speaking of which, she clearly did her homework on some of the stuff she used to build the game's world, however small it may be.

Raide's art shines, as well. Not much to say here. You'll know from screenshots whether it's your thing or not. I love it, personally.

If you buy in, be prepared to do a lot of reading. Most visual novel fans are no stranger to this, but the amount of sheer walls of verbosity in this game took me by surprise, and I've played quite a few VNs in my time.

406745.review:
Analogue: A Hate Story, the spiritual sequel to Digital: A Love Story, may be light on traditional "gameplay", but is nonetheless an amazing accomplishment. As you search through the archives of a long-lost Korean space colonization vessal Mugunghwa, the story unfolds in a way that is uniquely part game, part novel, but ulitmately so much more immersive than you could imagine. The writing is top-notch, and the story is absolutely unforgettable. I found myself playing late into the night, telling myself "just one more log..."

I give Analogue: A Hate Story the highest recommendation. Games with truly intelligent, well researched, memorable narratives are far and few in between. Thankfully, Love delivers in spades. If you are not convinced, try her previous titles: Don't take it personally, babe, it just ain't your story and Digital: A Love Story. Both free, both great.

A very good read, and hopefully one of many visual novels to eventually make their way on steam. There isn't much interaction except one part where you're basically working with a dos interface under a time limit, but the writing is solid, and finding out about the conflict from the 2 noble korean families, and why exactly the ship fell that day is quite engrossing.

Around halfway through you basically find out who did it, but the real interesting part is why. There's also the transformation of a typical young modern girl with no interest in silly things like marriage at such a young age in to a docile, quiet and subserviant wife, clinging on only to the joys of sex with her arranged husband and counting the days she has left; forgetting exactly why she fought back, forgetting why she resisted and what she had thought to gain from it.

Written and developed by Christine Love of Digital: A Love Story fame, it's certaintly worth a whirl of the demo at least if you enjoy a good read~

2371756.review:
If you don't care for visual novels, or if you don't like to read at all, then don't bother. Otherwise, Analogue: A Hate Story is definitely worth getting.

A term worth knowing:
- Mugunhwa : a spacecraft of some sort that carried an entire colony for the purpose of... well, colonization, I guess.

Gameplay:
It's a novel. You click. Don't be stupid.

Plot(?):
The story itself is presented through files unlocked by interacting with both *Hyun-ae and *Mute. From the ambiguous degredation of the culture in the Mugunghwa [from modern values to that of a more patriarchal -or medieval- culture], to the relationships between the people involved within the ship, Analogue is very well written.

Characters:
*Hyun-ae and *Mute are pretty much opposites: *Hyun-ae being a more contemporary female whereas *Mute behaves like an old-fashioned one, albeit a little angry. They are both likeable in their own ways, ways that you'll see if you buy this.

Conclusion:
Get it.

4877336.review:
First things first: it's a visual novel. If that's not your thing, this game offers no significantly different mechanics to win you over.

That said, it is one of the best games I've ever played. As an impartial observer of the past, you try to understand an entirely different people who lost their history and culture while isolated from the rest of humanity. You know they all died suddenly and it doesn't take long to figure out how. It's the "why" that drives you to complete this games gut-wrenching story, knowing all the while that it will be a horrific conclusion. 

There is nothing happy about this game. It's the kind of story with characters that make you feel physically ill and events that make you shudder or at times angry. At any point in time, you can interact with two characters: one who disapproves of the world you're exploring and one who defends it. 

In the end, it's a brilliantly written morality play where any good, justice or kindness are hard to find.

4316887.review:
Not what I expected at all, in a positive way. The description makes this look like some kind of dating game (a very small, neglectable part is though), but instead, you get a deep and exciting story.
Analogue: A Hate Story is a visual epistolary novel, kind of an e-book with interactivity. The 4 to 5 hour story (you can 100% the game in about 7 to 8 hours if you set the right saves) centers around the events on a space colony ending up in an disaster killing everyone on the ship, including a girl put in stasis for centuries waking up in a deeply misogynistic society and the two AIs who hate each other and have been alone in the system for 600 years. The goal of the game is to find the saved logs and explore them, revealing the scandals, secrets and connections leading to the fall of the Mugunghwa.

VERDICT: Very short, but great game if you are okay with having to read a lot and not having a "real" game. Amazing storytelling, 9/10

Ainda assim, é uma novela interativa muito legal. A história dos "nobres" principais que habitam a nave é muito boa, bastante densa psicologicamente, e para lá de adulta. 4395415.review:
"Why did you kill all those people?"

This was one of the first times asking a question in a game had me so scared. It was simply due to the fact that I didn't want to know the answer, scared not only for my own sake, but for the sake of the AI that I was asking the question.

"Analogue: A Hate Story" lives up to it's name. It boils down to the notion of hatred, and how everything went to shit by the time you arrived at the scene. Its a genre blender, featuring Computer Console commands, and CSI detective work in a game that seemed to be billed as a visual novel/dating sim.

You are a information contractor, who has the job of retrieving the data files of the "Mugunghwa", the korean spaceship colony that dissappeared hundreds of years ago and was barely found on your companie's sensors. How you choose to handle the story is up to you.

The story's path is rather appalling and tragic, but totally satisfying. The AI's are great characters too.

Get this game.

5094438.review: Great game with a moving story.

3884120.review:
A visual novel/adventure game. Colony ship was sent from Earth to distant stars but disappeared without a trace. Six hundred years later it was found drifting through space. Player’s task is to download ship archives and logs, but soon they will find out details behind tragedy that took place on board and led to ships demise. Two AIs could help the player, but each one is unreliable narrator. 

This title holds special significance of being the first visual novel released on Steam.

Visual novel is a very niche genre and arguments are still raging if they can be considered "games" at all. Typical VN does not have much of "gameplay" but require a lot of reading; user input is limited to selecting one of answers in dialogues. On top of that, Analogue is very minimalistic graphically: it has only two drawn characters and mostly clean white backgrounds. However, Analogue provides additional means of player interaction - a computer command line in which you type to "hack" the system, gain access to various logs and move the story forward; it has even timed sequence when you have to prevent ship's reactor from exploding.

Not too lengthy, with nice music and intriguing mystery story this can be excellent entry-level visual novel. Don't hate Analogue, give it a try.

3448312.review: Really nice and original game. Maybe have not so much action, but atmosphere is simply amazing. Worth to play, if you like Science Fiction.

1650666.review:
Analogue's pacing was spot on as Christine Love continuously keeps the reader engaged in the story and the dialogue with the likeable AI heroines. The actual setting itself is highly plausible with believable journal entries and character interactions. There wasn't a moment where my suspension of disbelief was broken, allowing me to immerse myself into this enjoyable, albeit short, story.

The overall presentation was excellent; while it may be a superficial thing, I haven't seen a physical layout in a visual novel this aesthetically pleasing in a long time.

That being said, Analogue does leave something to be desired. While the entire tale is told in its entirely and its loose ends are cleaned up nicely, it left me feeling unfulfilled. At the end of the day, Analogue is less of a game and more of an interactive story. If you aren't the kind of person who enjoys reading, you're probably going to want to pass over this one. I would give this game a solid B+; I highly recommend it.

4480497.review:
Analouge: A Hate Story is a a visual novel, with a fine story, great music, and I wanted to keep playing, trying to figure out what happened so long ago. Pale Bride's story makes you cry.

Story starts out with way too many names, but you start to figure out which ones matter. I know they want you to buy the soundtrack, but this game still could have used a jukebox of sorts. Achievements don't seem to work atm...

I'll be keeping my eyes out for the next visual novel on Steam.

4227169.review:
It a giant horror story in the form of a video game.

There isn't much with gameplay in this, it mainly reading. 
But the story draws you in a lot. (At least for me)

You are the one person that finds this spaceship in the middle of space, abandoned.  You later find out that that same ship was lost a thousand years ago and was supposed to hold the first space civilization.

However something had gone wrong, as you are on the ship, you find 2 Ai's and they have logs for you to read.

The game is set up as if you are on a computer the whole time, it's a nice interface. :3

The story is also set up like those Goosebump books from way back that let you choose your own path/death :D

Play this 'game' if you want to read a really good romance/drama story.  It was written very well, if this had a real book, I'd buy it <3

240643.review: Good emotional story with enough character interaction to get you invested.  Lot's of reading.  Just enough command line gameplay to be fun without needing deep machanics.

1641781.review:
I didn't know what I was getting myself into when I first launched the Demo for Analogue: A Hate Story. All I knew was my opinions on visual novel games were shifting and I was in the mood for a sci fi story. 

My initial thoughts were thus...

"What Da Fuq am I playing?!? I'm shifting through dead people's blog entries on a derelict space vessel that somehow became feudal Korea!?!? Why's the ship's AI dressed as a teenage schoolgirl and explaining how women weren't included into family trees to me!?!? I can't pronouce any of these goddamn names?!?!"

It was borderline maddening, I felt like i was missing something and pressed on with the full game, hoping I would find the hidden meaning of Analogue.

And man I did...

Analogue, although appearing very basic, even rudimentry at face value; is one of the best, most cleverly written story I have ever enecountered in a game. What begun as what seemed an unassuring story twists into a dark, unsettlingly detailed tale about the lives of the people who lived centuries before you whose world inexplicably came to a sudden end. And as you read more you feel it, the mounting fear and tension inside you, unable to divine the story's next turn. As the tidbits of the plot are revealed non-linearly, you start conceiving your own nightmare scenario. Its a lot like reading a suspensful horror novel; its not the words that scare, its your own imagination that conjures the most unimagination thing possible. Thats what Analogue makes you do, it makes you visualize a world you cannot even relate too by our modern perspective and bias. Than add in what must be one of the scariest twenty minutes in my gaming life, as well as multiple endings; and what you have is a sublime testament to narrative, pacing and delivery in gaming, or storytelling for that matter.

1467265.review: Very unique and interesting. Strong, mature themes. Unique setting. Recommended!

3118642.review:
This game is more like detective game mixed in a with chose your own adventure novel but is affected more so by what you choose to find out and how.  Do mind you, there is a lot of reading in this game, but it's not without some memorable characters as well as AI personalities that change their behavior as well as what they reveal to you depending on your research/reading and answers.

The game is set in the future and played through a pseudo command console/user inference with human-like AI personalities that react to what logs/mini-stories you show them as well as how you respond to their questions. 

Advice for enjoying this game: look for a character you care about and dedicate yourself to finding out more about them.  Or...if you find yourself unimpressed by the people you're reading about, try digging up dirt on the AI's that are trying to assist you, there's some bizarre twists for all of them.

2620559.review: Really good "game." More of a search for a story.  Either way, I was entertained trying to put the pieces together and develop a coherent plot.  This was meant for a mature audience, and not in a friendly, playful way.

412744.review: A well and uniquely told story, "Analogue: A Hate Story," is surprisingly moving. This is a visual novel, not a game, really--be prepared for words. 1564019.review:
I was sceptical at first, but after trying out the demo I was hooked. Don't be fooled by the minimal interface or anime-style characters if either bother you - this game has a story to tell and does it in a gripping way, breaking elements into bite-size chunks that make you beg for more.
After playing the demo for its full length, I bought the game at full-price and continued to complete it in one sitting. For an entirely narrative-based game, a good 3 hours of gripping gameplay is quite a feat, and with only half the content unlocked and plenty more endings to see, there's a lot of space for replayability! Concept art prizes for completion percentage, too!
All I can say is 'give the demo a try'. You'll probably either love it or hate it, but I certainly loved it. This game hit all the right spots at the right times, emotionally connected me with a character, strained that trust, then ultimately rewarded both her and I with catharsis. Worth every penny I paid.

While its status as a "game" is somewhat debatable, Analogue is a fine example of how VNs can both entertain the player/reader and explore some very interesting and deep ideas through the use of well-written and engaging narrative. Love's dialogue feels very natural, although there's not a terribly large amount of it, and the log files string you along in such a way that you're always eager to read the next one.

If you're at all interested in this game, and even if you don't think you are, I would highly recommend giving the demo a spin. If you like the demo, you'll love the game. And while you can purchase the game directly from Steam, you can also support the author by buying the game from http://www.ahatestory.com and sending Love an email requesting a Steam key for it.

2307716.review:
If you don't like reading, then this isn't the game for you. 

But if you're the kind of person who, when they're playing any other sort of video game likes to read all the optional journal entries and log files of the departed denizens of whatever ruin you're slicin' up monsters in, then you'll find this a pleasant surprise.

The visual novel format does much to immerse you inside the game's world--you're not just a guy reading a book, you're a guy on a spaceship drifting next to an abandoned hulk reading the ship's logs about a doomed voyage while two AIs who aren't telling you the whole story comment on them.

It's not "anime". It's a story about politics, family rivalry, and inhumanity. It's one of the first "visual novels" to remember that the word "novel" is there for a reason.

If you can deal with a lot of reading and little else and are curious what happened to the space ship and it's crew (and aren't put off by reading A LOT about weddings and ancient anti-women polotics) then it's something worth playing. Throughout the course of Analogue, you dig through correspondence of the passengers of the ship and share it with two of the ship's AIs, who seem to be at cross purposes. How you interact with them changes what information you have access to and ultimately what you come away with in the end. 

Analogue is a visual novel, so if you never liked them, it's not going to change now. But otherwise, it's an interesting one with something worth saying.

If you're willing to pay a premium to support indie developers, grab Analogue right away. Otherwise, hold off for a sale price -- it IS pretty short.

1096032.review:
I took a look at Christine Love's Google+ stream, in which she says that the *first draft* of the game had some 57000 words. So yes, there's a lot to read. I have now found two of the endings (one being the premature one) and I have, apparently, read altogether about 87% of all the entries in the game, so there's still things for me to do. So far, I've spent 3.1 hours on the game.

Adventure games are often "disposable" - play through it once and you're done. Sure, you won't be playing this as much as a multiplayer FPS, but I'd expect the second playthrough being far more interesting than it was in, say, Syberia.

Of course, if you're the type to throw "tl;dr" around like rice at a wedding, you're not going to like this. If not, well, I suggest you give the demo a shot. It took me 40 minutes to clear, and I think the demo was quite indicative of what the rest of the game would be like.

1642831.review:
Before you go any further, a primer: This is a game that is designed to be finished like a book. It is not one where you pit your -supposed- skills against computer- or human-controlled opponents. It offers a fairly refreshing twist to the way stories are normally told.

First off, let me say upfront that if action is all that matters to you (and/or you're not a fan of visual novels), don't even bother looking at this game - you're entirely incompatible with it and simply won't think much of it, so save yourself time and don't bother with the demo (or reading the rest of this review). In fact, the screenshots on the game's page are all you will ever see in the game, the rest is up to your imagination. You won't see the [i]Mugunghwa[/i] or its interior, nor your own ship's. There is no voice acting, and all you will ever interact with are two AI individuals, and an override terminal through which you can switch between the two and perform some other tasks.

However, if you are willing to look beyond that, the storyline is actually pretty interesting. It's really hard to explain it without spoiling anything, and I think the description on the game's page does a fairly good job of explaining the context. I recommend giving the demo a go, it's well worth your time if you're willing to look deeper than the seemingly simple first impression - I was already captivated by the storyline in the demo, and so much so that it successfully persuaded me to get the full game.

Unfortunately, if you're still unfamiliar with the names, the questions the AI occasionally asks of your opinion will sometimes catch you off guard as you struggle to recall who they're talking about, and the inability to refer to the family tree at that juncture only serves to compound the problem.

At some point in the game, the override terminal will temporarily become an integral part of [i]your[/i] story, so don't forget how to use it (although it should be easy to figure out how). It would be nice if it supported tabbed commands (i.e. pressing tab to autocomplete partially entered commands) and command history (i.e. using the up and down cursor keys to speed up entry of repeated commands) just like its real life counterparts, since at the abovementioned point in the game, you'll find yourself typing largely the same commands over and over.

All in all, a piece well worthy of your time.

3800854.review: Okay. I'm gonna be honest here. This is not your typical game. In fact, I'm not sure if I can call it a game. For starters, it is a visual novel, which is at best an atypical kind of game. Second, you will not have fun playing it. In fact, you will be appalled, /horrified/ by this software at times. As more and more information is revealed to you, you are told a story about thoroughly contrasting values, misogyny and arranged marriages in a society where people are ignorant of the very environment around them and women are treated like things, not like people. With all this said, though, it's worth going through it, because it invites you to think about how society can regress into archaism when it doesn't find a way to progress and, apart of the misogyny and arranged marriage dilemma, it also offers a question: When computers become advanced enough, what makes them different from humans? If you're a visual novel enthusiast and like things that make you think, you should have this.

40592058.review:
Analogue: A Hate Story ist eine mit Renpy erstellte Visual Novel (im Folgenden mit "VN" abgekürzt). Renpy ist eine frei verfügbare und kostenlos nutzbare Entiwcklungsumgebung speziell für VNs, welche es vor allem Anfänger leicht macht, in die Materie der VN-Entwicklung einzusteigen. So ist es kein Wunder, dass es Unmengen an Erstlingswerken von Hinz und Kunz auf dem Markt gibt, von denen der Großteil eher nicht so gut ist.

Die Frage, die sich hier stellt, ist nun lediglich, ob dieses Spiel es wert ist, dass man dafür Geld und Zeit darin investiert.

Das Setting ist durchaus interessant: Man spielt eine Art externen Mitarbeiter oder Dienstleister, der für eine gewisse "historical society from the outer colonies" ein im Weltall gestrandetes uraltes Raumschiff untersuchen muss. Die Spielfigur betritt deshalb das Raumschiff und klinkt sich in die Boardsysteme ein, wo sie sich entweder mit einer von zwei künstlichen Intelligenzen unterhalten muss, oder in einer Befehlszeilenkonsole Konsolenbefehle eingibt. Mithilfe von Logdateien, die der Spieler nach und nach im Bordcomputer findet, muss er das Geheimnis und die Vergangenheit des Raumschiffs rekonstruieren.

Was sich auf dem Papier durchaus spannend anhört, erweist sich in der Praxis als ein bisschen anstrengend. Die minimalistische Oberfläche und die Befehlszeilenkonsole wirken einerseits immersiv, was gut ist, andererseits aber auch etwas eintönig. Der Spieler fühlt sich zwar wie ein Ermittler vor einem Computerbildschirm und muss auch ab und an Befehlszeilenkommandos in ein schwarzes Konsolenfenster eintippen, doch gerade das und die wenig abwechslungsreiche grafische Darstellung der KIs lassen das Spiel optisch recht schnell langweilig werden.
Die Recherchearbeit an sich ist okay, doch muss man oft Logdateien mehrmals öffnen, um zu überprüfen, ob man bereits die KI dazu befragt hat. Hier könnte man das Spiel nutzerfreundlicher gestalten.
Das Wichtigste ist jedoch die Geschichte, denn wegen dieser interessieren wir uns überhaupt für das Spiel und es lässt sich hierbei kurz und knapp sagen: Ja, sie lohnt sich.

Zusammenfassend kann man also nur sagen, dass sich das Spiel durchaus lohnt und mit einer Laufzeit von etwa fünf Stunden auch zu schaffen ist. Die Geschichte ist recht traurig, aber interessant und in etwa auf dem Niveau eines Jugendromans. Die koreanische Sci-Fi-Umgebung ist hierbei grundsätzlich eine angenehme Abwechslung, im Gegensatz zum typischen japanischen Schulleben oder dem europäischen oder japanischen Fantasy-Mittelalter. Grafisch hat das Spiel wenig Abwechslung zu bieten, was aber auch größtenteils durch die Spielmechanik bedingt ist, welche wiederum sehr interessant ist.

Preislich halte ich das Spiel mit 10 EUR bei etwa fünf Stunden Laufzeit für zu teuer. Ich empfehle, auf einen Sale zu warten und es für nicht mehr als 5 EUR zu kaufen.

Wer auf ähnliche Spiele steht, kann sich das einige Jahre danach erschienene Spiel Her Story anschauen, welches statt Logs auf realverfilmte Videosequenzen (Interviews) setzt und auch mit einem angemesseneren Preis (etwa 6 EUR) daherkommt.

40387254.review:
Eres un investigador que ha recibido el encargo de investigar una nave espacial inhabitada por siglos. ¡Manos a la obra! Establece conexión con el ordenador central de la nave y descubre todo lo que puedas. Casi se me olvida, la IA de la nave te ayudara en tu tarea, con más o menos acierto.

En esta visual novel, la historia es contada mediante los "logs" o registros que los últimos habitantes de Mugunghwa dejaron antes de desaparecer. Las dos IAs complementarán la información de estos registros con sus propios "recuerdos". Los fragmentos de la historia están desordenados, se desbloquean interactuando con la IA, aun así no es difícil de seguir.

Jugablemente, al contrario que la mayoría de novelas visuales (al menos las que yo he jugado), Analogue nos ofrece algo más. Durante el transcurso del juego, usaremos varias veces la terminal para realizar ciertas acciones mediante comandos, lastima que esto no sea un poco más frecuente. Me hubiese gustado ver más eventos [spoiler]como el del reactor[/spoiler] pero esta mecánica solo aparece una vez. Los comandos, excepto dos o tres en concreto, solo se van a usar en una ocasión.

Al poco de comenzar la historia, se hace patente que sucedió algo en la nave que transformo la sociedad en una con elementos del feudalismo (supongo que se basa en alguna etapa de la edad media coreana). Una sociedad, en la que de un momento a otro a las mujeres se les prohíbe aprender a leer o a escribir. Toda la información anterior a esta etapa ha desaparecido por completo de la nave, así que solo nos queda investigar los eventos que llevaron a esta sociedad "feudal" al colapso completo.

En cuanto a las ilustraciones, cumplen sin más. La banda sonora acompaña bien los eventos de la historia.

[h1]En resumen[/h1]
Una experiencia entretenida y ligera, con una jugabilidad algo distinta a lo que se suele ver en el genero, cuya historia si bien no es tan impresionante, cumple de sobra. Por otra parte las mecánicas que se plantean podrían haberse usado algo más.

40212549.review: I can't sing the praises of this game enough. I personally love the art style. Many games have tried the whole you're a person playing the game, think Assasain's Creed, but Analogue is a prime example of a game that really nails it. I loved getting the whole story over several plays, it was very interesting to see how biased each viewpoint was, only reading or listening to one persons perspective would leave you with a flawed idea of the reality of the situation, which really adds to the realism of the situation. I'm not a fan of games that give you mind-numbingly vast amounts of notes or computer entries filled with clunky exposition and boring history, I feel that is best intuited by the player. But, I was pleasantly surprised to see that even though the game is built upon the premise of reading computer entries, it isn't a chore to read each one, I would get excited whenever I obtained a new one. Seriously, if you like story-based games you MUST get this, I still think about it even though it has been months and months since I played it.

40024601.review:
12.2.2018. Game #14

ONLY IF IT’S ON SALE

I apologize for starting my review like this but it has to be said before anything else. I was about to give this game a recommendation without a second thought, until I looked at the price. I got this game as part of humble bundle and it was a joy to play (read) through it, but 10 euros alone for a game that’s basically a short story is not worth it. I have read kindle books that were 5 times longer than this one and that cost 3 times less. So again, it’s worth it, but only if it’s on sale. 

Analogue: A Hate Story isn’t so much a visual novel as it is a book with scattered pages. The gameplay consists of a lot of reading and unlocking more pages as you progress through reading. Basically… it’s like reading a short story. I really wouldn’t call it a visual novel as visual novels usually have a lot more than this game.

This game consists of a lot of diary logs and letters (most of which you will have to unlock), a command terminal and 2 characters. It’s not a lot even for a visual novel, however, it’s entertaining enough that I can recommend it.

Without spoiling too much, the story is about you (a space explorer/salvager) who gets a job to board an old abandoned spaceship that used to be a home to a colony of people eons ago. All the people died a long time ago but some computers are still running and it’s your job to salvage whatever’s left on it. So you board the ship, turn on the computer and meet an AI. In the beginning there are only a few pages and you can’t even salvage them since you are missing the administrator password. So what do you do? Well, you can read through the pages you have and piece together what happened. This is where the AI comes into play. The AI is a cute girl named *Hyun-ae who is willing to help you with your mission, provided you pay attention to the story.

As you read through the available pages, you can talk to *Hyun-ae and ask her about her opinion of the matter. This way she uses her abilities to dig out more journal entries and help you figure out what exactly happened on the ship you are on. You can finish the game as soon as you figure out what the administrator password is but, if you are like me, you will want to see everything until the end and get some closure before you are satisfied.

The story you read through the diary focuses mostly on the events between very rich families. In the beginning, it’s very boring. You read about the daily lives of these two families who are trying to make it big in the world (colony) by using arrange marriages and political power. It becomes very clear that, despite this being the future, everyone lives like they are in the dark ages. The most overused cliché about the dark ages is the treatment of women as objects. Somehow, despite it being the future, women have lost all credibility and are just treated as baby makers, cooks, and housewives. So, again, the story starts in a very boring tone. You read about one family, a little bit about the other family and how they are struggling to get heirs and how having daughters is a great dishonor but then everything changes when one character gets introduced: The Pale Bride. Unlike everyone else who was on board the ship, the pale bride is actually from a modern time where women were treated with the respect and by reading her diary entries you finally start to make sense of what is going on. If you are keen on finding out what exactly transpired in on the ship, you are in for a story filled with arranged marriages, politics, sex, lust and a lot of other dark elements. If you reach the end of the game, you will realize why it’s called “A Hate Story”.

Just to make one thing clear: if you don’t like reading and don’t want to read, this is not a game for you. In fact, it barely feels like a game. It feels more like a reading class where after every few pages, you discuss what you’ve read with the class only to get more reading. Does this make the game fun? NO. However, does the game have an entertaining story to tell? ABSOLUTELY YES.

Despite the insane price of 10 euros for a rather short story that you can read through in a few hours, I can’t NOT recommend this game. It’s a lot of fun piecing together what happened and the story will keep you on the edge of your seat until the very end.  In short, this is a great story.

If you are in a mood for a good story where you get to make some very light decisions and maybe get a few different ending, WAIT FOR A SALE, and get this game. For 10 euros, it’s not worth it, but for maybe 5, it’s definitely worth a buy.

Next game: Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures
